revision.text:
{{short description|Species of plant}} {{for|the common ornamental plant|Ficus elastica}} {{speciesbox |image =Hevea_brasiliensis_-_KÃ¶hlerâs_Medizinal-Pflanzen-071.jpg |genus = Hevea |species = brasiliensis |authority = [[Johannes MÃ¼ller Argoviensis|MÃ¼ll.Arg.]] }}
'''''Hevea brasiliensis''''', the '''ParÃ¡ rubber tree''', '''''sharinga'' tree, seringueira''', or, most commonly, the '''rubber tree''' or '''rubber plant''', is a tree belonging to the [[family (biology)|family]] [[Euphorbiaceae]]. It is the most economically important member of the genus ''[[Hevea]]'' because the milky [[latex]] extracted from the tree is the primary source of [[natural rubber]].
==Description== ''H. brasiliensis'' is a tall deciduous tree growing to a height of up to {{convert|43|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} in the wild, but cultivated trees are usually much smaller because drawing off the latex restricts the growth of the tree. The trunk is cylindrical and may have a swollen, bottle-shaped base. The bark is some shade of brown, and the inner bark oozes [[latex]] when damaged. The leaves have three leaflets and are spirally arranged. The inflorescence include separate male and female flowers. The flowers are pungent, creamy-yellow and have no petals. The fruit is a capsule that contains three large seeds; it opens explosively when ripe.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://powo.science.kew.org/taxon/urn:lsid:ipni.org:names:349913-1 |title=''Hevea brasiliensis'' (Willd. ex A.Juss.) MÃ¼ll.Arg. |work=Plants of the World online |publisher=Kew Science |accessdate=31 March 2017}}</ref>
==Rubber tree plantation== [[Image:Hevea semillas2.jpg|thumb|150px|right|Rubber tree seeds]] In the wild, the tree can reach a height of up to {{convert|140|ft|m}}. The white or yellow latex occurs in latex vessels in the [[Bark (botany)|bark]], mostly outside the [[phloem]]. These vessels spiral up the tree in a right-handed [[helix]] which forms an [[angle]] of about 30 degrees with the horizontal, and can grow as high as 45 ft.<ref name=FAO/>
In plantations, the trees are generally smaller for two reasons: 1) trees grow more slowly when they are tapped for latex, and 2) trees are generally cut down after only 30 years, because latex production declines as trees age, and they are no longer economically productive. The tree requires a tropical or subtropical climate with a minimum of about 1,200 mm per year of rainfall, and no frost.<ref name=eb/> If frost does occur, the results can be disastrous for production. One frost can cause the rubber from an entire plantation to become brittle and break once it has been refined."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/006/AD221E/AD221E01.htm |title=The rubber tree |author= |date= |work= |publisher=FAO |accessdate=29 May 2017}}</ref>
===Latex tapping=== {{Main|Rubber tapping}} [[Image:The face of rubber tree's trunk.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Rubber tree trunk]] [[image:Tapped rubber tree.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Latex being collected from an incised rubber tree and a bucket of collected latex]] Harvesters make incisions across the latex vessels, just deep enough to tap the vessels without harming the tree's growth, and the latex is collected in small buckets. This process is known as [[rubber tapping]]. Latex production is highly variable from tree to tree and across clone types.<ref name=FAO>{{cite web |url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/006/AD221E/AD221E06.htm |title=Rubber tapping |publisher=FAO |accessdate=29 May 2017}}</ref>
===Wood harvesting=== {{Main|Rubberwood}} As latex production declines with age, rubber trees are generally felled when they reach the age of 25 to 30 years. The earlier practice was to burn the trees, but in recent decades, the wood has been harvested for furniture making.<ref name=FAO/>
==History== The South American rubber tree grew only in the [[Amazon rainforest]], and increasing demand and the discovery of the [[vulcanization]] procedure in 1839 led to the [[Amazon rubber boom|rubber boom]] in that region, enriching the cities of [[BelÃ©m]], [[SantarÃ©m, ParÃ¡|SantarÃ©m]], [[Manaus]] and [[Iquitos]], [[Peru]], of 1840 to 1913. In Brazil, the initial name of the plant was ''parÃ¡ rubber tree.'' The name of the tree derives from [[State of GrÃ£o-ParÃ¡ and Rio Negro|GrÃ£o-ParÃ¡ and Rio Negro]] or only GrÃ£o-ParÃ¡ (Great-ParÃ¡), the largest Brazilian province until 1850, the capital of which is BelÃ©m, where most of the fluid, also called ''[[latex]]'', was extracted and exported. In Peru, in addition to the hispanic-speaking countries of the Amazon region, the name given was ''Ã¡rbol del caucho'', with the fluid extracted called ''caucho''. These trees were used to obtain rubber by the natives who inhabited its geographical distribution. The [[Olmec]] people of [[Mesoamerica]] extracted and produced similar forms of primitive rubber from analogous latex-producing trees such as ''[[Castilla elastica]]'' as early as 3,600 years ago. The rubber was used, among other things, to make the balls used in the [[Mesoamerican ballgame]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.maya-archaeology.org/Mayan_anthropology_ethnography_archaeology_art_history_iconography_epigraphy_ethnobotany/rubber_hule_Castilla_elastica_incense_idols_ball_game_balls_Guatemala_Chiapas_Mexico_Belize_Hevea_brasiliensis.php |title=Introduction to Rubber Usage among the Maya |author=Langenheim, J.H. |date=13 January 2010 |publisher=Maya Archaeology |accessdate=29 May 2017}}</ref> Early attempts were made in 1873 to grow ''H. brasilensis'' outside [[Brazil]]. After some effort, 12 seedlings were germinated at the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]]. These were sent to [[India]] for cultivation, but died. A second attempt was then made, some 70,000 seeds being smuggled to Kew in 1875, by [[Henry Wickham (explorer)|Henry Wickham]], in the service of the British Empire.<ref name=df>"The Brazilian Armed Forces: Current changes, new challenges", ''Dreifuss, R. Armand''. International Seminar Research Committee Armed Forces and Society, Romania, 2002. Retrieved August 19, 2009 from {{cite web |url=http://www.nestbrasil.com/rest/page8/files/rested1-dreyfus.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-08-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090731102816/http://www.nestbrasil.com/rest/page8/files/rested1-dreyfus.pdf |archivedate=2009-07-31 |df= }}</ref>{{RP|55}}<ref name=gp>"Amazon - The Animation", ''Greepeace Digital''. Artificial Environments, n/d. Retrieved August 19, 2009 from {{cite web |url=http://www.ae-pro.com/preview.php?preid=31&pro=Amazon |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-08-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707090719/http://www.ae-pro.com/preview.php?preid=31&pro=Amazon |archivedate=2011-07-07 |df= }}</ref><ref name=mag>"Acre: HistÃ³ria e etnologia", ''Marco AntÃ³nio GonÃ§alves (Org.)''. NÃºcleo de Etnologia IndÃ­gena LaboratÃ³rio de Pesquisa Social/IFCS - UFRJ, n/d. Retrieved August 19, 2009 from http://eduardoeginacarli.blogspot.com/2007_07_01_archive.html</ref> About four percent of these germinated, and in 1876, about 2,000 seedlings were sent, in [[Wardian case]]s, to [[Ceylon]] (modern day Sri Lanka) and 22 were sent to the Botanic Gardens in [[Singapore]]. Once established outside its native country, rubber was extensively propagated in the British colonies. Rubber trees were brought to the botanical gardens at [[Bogor|Buitenzorg]], Java, in 1883.<ref name="winchester">{{cite book | last = Winchester | first = Simon | authorlink = Simon Winchester | title = [[Krakatoa: The Day the World Exploded, August 27, 1883]] |pages=223â224 | publisher = HarperCollins | year = 2003 | isbn = 0-06-621285-5 }}</ref> By 1898, a rubber plantation had been established in [[British Malaya|Malaya]], with imported Chinese field workers being the dominant work force in rubber production in the early 20th-century.<ref>Harold A. Crouch, ''Economic Change, Social Structure, and the Political System in Southeast Asia'', Institute of Southeast Asian Studies: Singapore 1985, pp. 16â17 {{ISBN|9971-988-23-2}}</ref> Today, most rubber tree plantations are in [[South Asia|South]] and [[Southeast Asia]], the top rubber producing countries in 2011 being Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, India and Vietnam.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://top5ofanything.com/list/7738a992/Rubber-Producing-Countries |title=The Top 5 Rubber Producing Countries |publisher=Top 5 of Anything |accessdate=29 May 2017}}</ref>
The cultivation of the tree in South America (Amazon) ended early in the 20th century because of [[blight]].<ref name=eb>"Elastomer-The rubber tree", ''EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica'', 2008</ref> The blight, called South American leaf blight, is caused by the [[Ascomycota|ascomycetes]], ''[[Microcyclus ulei]]''<ref>[http://www.plantwise.org/knowledgebank/datasheet.aspx?dsid=33893 South American Leaf Blight of rubber (Microcyclus ulei)], plantwise.org</ref> or ''Pseudocercospora ulei''.<ref>[http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0104750#pone-0104750-g006 Erasing the Past: A New Identity for the Damoclean Pathogen Causing South American Leaf Blight of Rubber]</ref>
==Environmental concerns== The toxicity of arsenic to [[insect]]s, [[bacteria]], and [[fungi]] has led to the heavy use of [[arsenic trioxide]] on rubber plantations, especially in [[Malaysia]].<ref name=Ullmann>{{Ullmann | author = Sabina C. Grund, Kunibert Hanusch, Hans Uwe Wolf | title = Arsenic and Arsenic Compounds | doi = 10.1002/14356007.a03_113.pub2}}</ref>
The majority of the rubber trees in Southeast Asia are clones of varieties highly susceptible to the South American leaf blightâ''Microcyclus ulei''. For these reasons, environmental historian Charles C. Mann, in his 2011 book, ''1493: Uncovering the New World Columbus Created'', predicted that the Southeast Asian rubber plantations will be ravaged by the blight in the not-too-distant future, thus creating a potential calamity for international industry.<ref>{{cite book|last=Mann|first=Charles C.|title=1493: Uncovering the New World Columbus Created|year=2011|publisher=Knopf|location=New York|isbn=978-0-307-26572-2}}</ref>
==Synonyms== The genus ''Hevea'' is also known as:
* '''''Caoutchoua''''' <small>[[J.F.Gmel.]]</small> * '''''Micrandra''''' <small> [[Benn.]] & [[Robert Brown (Scottish botanist from Montrose)|R.Br.]]</small> * '''''Siphonanthus''''' <small>[[Schreb.]] ex [[Henri Ernest Baillon|Baill.]]</small> * '''''Siphonia''''' <small>[[D.Richard]] ex [[Schreb.]]</small> * '''''Siphopnicna''''' <small>[[F.Jansen]] ex [[Schreb.]]</small>
==See also== * ''[[Castilla elastica]]''âthe principal source of latex rubber among the pre-Columbian [[Mesoamerica|MesoAmerican]] peoples * [[List of plants of Amazon Rainforest vegetation of Brazil]] * [[Congo Free State Propaganda War|Red Rubber Scandal]]âwas one of the first humanitarian global campaigns but concerned the rubber vine species * [[Rubber seed oil]] * [[Rubberwood]]
==Notes== {{Reflist|2}}
==References== {{refbegin}} * [http://www.abiarb.com.br Brazilian Association of Rubber GoodsâABIARB] * [http://www.anip.com.br National Association Tire IndustryâANIP (Brazil)] * [http://www.apabor.org.br Sao Paulo's Association of Rubber Producers and ProcessorsâAPABOR (Brazil)] * [http://volksgrun.com/bio%20rubber/ Bio ecological production of rubber without fertilizing in MalaysiaâBioRubber] * [http://www.borrachanatural.agr.br Brazilian Natural Rubber] * [http://www.lateks.com.br LATEKS magazine (Brazil)] * [http://www.seringueira.com Seringueira.com - Brazilian rubber tree consulting] * Zhang, J., Huss, V.A.R., Sun, X., Chang, K. and Pan, D. 2008. Morphology and phylogenetic position of a trebouxiophycean green algae (Chlorophyta) growing on the rubber tree, ''Hevea brasiliensis'', with the description of a new genus and species. ''Eur. J. Phycol.'' '''43(2)''': 185â193.
==External links== {{Commons category|Hevea brasiliensis}} * {{YouTube|id=UPMJVnxZLgQ|title=Extraction of Rubber}}

revision.comment: Undid revision 871392367 by [[Special:Contributions/144.85.150.15|144.85.150.15]] ([[User talk:144.85.150.15|talk]])not appropriate hatnote
revision.text:
'''Holznot''' (German for '''wood shortage''') is a historic term for an existing or imminent supply crisis of wood.
== Historical use == [[File:GemmageCrot.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Resin worker]]s were seen as outdated and damaging to modern forestry]] In particular, the concept was applied to Central Europe around the end of the 16th century till the start of the early 19th century in numerous sources. In almost all German-speaking regions, a wood shortage and resulting wood-saving measures became an important topic. <ref>[[Joachim Radkau]], Technik in Deutschland. Vom 18. Jahrhundert bis heute. Frankfurt/New York 2008, p. 74.</ref> <ref name = wood> [http://www.historeinonline.org/index.php/historein/article/viewFile/180/176 review of Joachim Radkau Wood: A History Cambridge: Polity Press, 2012. 399 pp. by Vaso Seirinidou University of Athens]</ref> Forestry and history scholars did not dispute the wood shortage ''per se'' for a long time. Besides the [[tragedy of the commons]] legend, the alleged Holznot was critical to motivate the shift from forest use as part of [[Subsistence economy|subsistence agriculture]] to modern professional forestry and was an important base of the development of modern forestry science around 1800. Around the 1980s, [[Environmental history|environmental historian]] [[Joachim Radkau]] raising doubts about the alleged 18th-century wood shortage started a research controversy among German historians, called the "Holznotdebatte". Radkau debated e.g. with [[Rolf Peter Sieferle]] about the existence, extent, and spatial and social impact of perceived or real existing wood shortages and the associated ideological and economic background.<ref name=wein>Elisabeth Weinberger: ''Waldnutzung und Waldgewerbe in Altbayern im 18. und beginnenden 19. Jahrhundert.'' Franz Steiner Verlag, Stuttgart 2001, {{ISBN|3-515-07610-7}}. (Sozial- und Wirtschaftsgeschichte: Beihefte Band 157)</ref><ref>Frank UekÃ¶tter, Umweltgeschichte im 19. und 20. Jahrhundert. EnzyklopÃ¤die deutscher Geschichte, Bd. 81, (hg. v. [[Lothar Gall]]), MÃ¼nchen 2007, S. 8. </ref> Radkau doubted the Holznot had existed at all. Similar as with the [[tragedy of the commons]] he saw a strong ideological motive to get rid of the traditional farmers' forest access.<ref name = wood/>
Radkau repeats [[Werner Sombart]]âs notion of the pre-industrial phase as a âWooden Ageâ, where wood constituted the key substance for fuel energy, construction and machinery. While Sombart was positive about the change to an "iron age", Radkau is critical about the alleged decline of âwooden civilisationâ. Before the industrial century, the âwood brakeâ, as he names it, was a component of stability, of the ecology and the traditional economic and social order. In connection with the first [[Berggeschrey| medieval mining rushes]] regional wood shortages gave rise to the first use of [[sustainability]] in German forestry.
However the situation began to change in the 16th century, as meeting point of the capitalist expansion and the formation of the absolutist state. From the 16th century, world maritime trade, housing construction in Europe and the mountain mining industry brought a sharp rise in timber consumption. The absolutist state asked for a new order of the use of forests and area property rights at the expense of livestock grazing and traditional forest use, as in [[Resin extraction]]. Complaints about wood shortages served according Radkau to legitimate state intervention and to exclude of traditional groups of users, as [[resin worker]]s and [[wood pasture]] in favour of more profitable timber consumers.<ref name = wood/>
== Peak wood == The term '''peak wood''' refers to the point in time when the maximum rate of wood harvesting is reached. The term 'peak' refers to the [[Hubbert peak]] of a resource. Thus peak wood and [[peak oil]] cannot be compared directly.<ref name=ind2010>{{cite web |url=http://www.independent.com/news/2010/apr/16/peak-wood/ |title= Peak Wood: The Importance of Being a Forest |publisher= Santa Barbara Independent |date= April 2010 |accessdate=16 April 2010 }}</ref><ref name=mm2010>{{cite web |url=http://www.miller-mccune.com/environment/peak-wood-nature-does-impose-limits-16596/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100604010753/http://www.miller-mccune.com/environment/peak-wood-nature-does-impose-limits-16596/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2010-06-04 |title=Peak Wood: Nature Does Impose Limits |author=John Perlin |publisher=Miller-McCune |date=June 2010 |accessdate=1 June 2010 }}</ref><ref name=am2005>{{cite web |url=http://tobyspeople.com/anthropik/2005/10/peak-wood/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100618055345/http://tobyspeople.com/anthropik/2005/10/peak-wood/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2010-06-18 |title=Peak Wood |publisher=The Anthropik Network |date=October 2005 |accessdate=21 October 2005 }}</ref> Unlike resources such as [[petroleum]], which are destroyed in use, wood continually grows and recycled, but it requires habitat (forests, woodland and timber plantations).
In the 2011 book ''[[Life Without Oil]]'' by [[Steve Hallett]], the author argues that the collapse of the [[Roman Empire]] may have been linked to a peak wood scenario in the Mediterranean basin. He suggests that, as wood had to be hauled from ever further away, the [[law of diminishing returns]] undermined the economic performance of Roman industry, leaving Rome vulnerable to the other, well documented problems of invasion and internal division. The issue is discussed as cautionary tale comparing it to contemporary society's potential fate under a post-[[peak oil]] scenario.<ref>{{cite book |title=Life Without Oil: Why We Must Shift to a New Energy Future |last=Hallett |first=Steve |authorlink= |year=2011 |publisher=Prometheus Books |location= |isbn= |page= |pages= |accessdate=24 July 2012 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9XhGp1vJ2wkC}}</ref> Its relevance for ancient and current times is however disputed strongly.
== Further reading == * Wood: A History. By Joachim Radkau, translated by Patrick Camiller (Cambridge, UK: Polity Press, 2012. viii plus 399 pp.) * [http://www.bafu.admin.ch/suchen/index.html?keywords=holznot&go_search=Suchen&lang=de&site_mode=intern&nsb_mode=yes&search_mode=AND#volltextsuche Swiss Bafu research Project Â«HolznotÂ» (18th/19th century)] * Rolf-JÃ¼rgen Gleitsmann: ''Rohstoffmangel und LÃ¶sungsstrategien: Das Problem der vorindustriellen Holzknappheit'', in: ''Technologie und Politik'' 16 (1980), S. 104-154. * Joachim Radkau: ''Technik in Deutschland. Vom 18. Jahrhundert bis heute.'' Frankfurt / New York 2008, {{ISBN|978-3-593-38689-8}}. * Joachim Radkau: ''Holzverknappung und KrisenbewuÃtsein im 18. Jahrhundert'', in: ''Geschichte und Gesellschaft'' 9 (1983), S. 513-543.
==See also== *[[Deforestation during the Roman period]]

revision.text:
{{-}} {{Infobox person | name = John Ormsbee Simonds <!-- Commented out because image was deleted: | image = johnsimonds.jpg --> | image_size = 200px | birth_date = {{birth date|1913|3|11|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Jamestown, North Dakota]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2005|5|6|1913|3|11|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] | occupation = Landscape Architect, Planner, and Environmentalist | spouse = Margorie Simonds | parents = Guy Wallace and Margueritte Simonds }} '''John Ormsbee Simonds''' was born in [[Jamestown, North Dakota]] on March 11, 1913. He was a visionary [[landscape architect]], planner, educator, and [[environmentalist]]. Simonds was an original modernist landscape architect and one of the most influential and well-known of his time.
== Career == In 1935 he graduated with a B.S. in Landscape Architecture from [[Michigan State University]]. He went on to receive a Master's from [[Harvard Graduate School of Design]]. After finishing school, Simonds and his brother Phil established their company, Simonds and Simonds, later known as Environmental Planning and Development Partnership. While continuing his company he published his first book, ''Landscape Architecture: The Shaping of Man's Natural Environment''. In 1973 Simonds received his first and most honorable award, the [[American Society of Landscape Architects|ASLA]] medal. Shortly after being awarded, Simonds released another publication titled, ''Earthscape: A Manual of Environmental Planning''. In 1983 and 1998 he released the second and then third edition of his publication ''Landscape Architecture''. Before his death in May 2005, Simonds received his last award, the ASLA President's Centennial Medal in 1998.
== Influences == The first most important influence was Simonds' father, Guy Wallace, a [[Presbyterian]] [[minister (Christianity)|minister]]. Simonds' father helped him to develop a love and appreciation for nature, and the ability to speak to others with great enthusiasm. As his designs developed, the use of incorporating nature with quality and balance became his foremost goal and attribute to design.
Simonds' design was also greatly influenced by his travels to [[Asia]]. He began to use aspects of the [[Zen]] [[philosophy]] and their idea of the garden being harmonious. Simonds wanted the garden to become a way for humans to create a relationship with plants. With his travels to Asia and studies under modern architects [[Walter Gropius]] and [[Marcel Breuer]] at [[Harvard]], Simonds' designs became the best they could be and remain a part of today's society, influencing rising architects.
== Accomplishments == The basis of Simonds' firm was centered on parks, recreational facilities, playgrounds, urban area and space, and many large gardens.
[[Mellon Square]], in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania|Pittsburgh]], was built in 1951 and is one of Simonds major designs. The garden was one of the first and few placed on top a parking garage. "Mellon Square was intended by Simonds to be an oasis, a civic movement, and a gathering space in the midst of downtown office towers."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tclf.org/pioneers/simonds.htm |author=Slade, Nancy |title=Remembering John Ormsbee Simonds, FASLA |year=2007 |publisher=The Cultural Landscape Foundation |accessdate=2008-05-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070222114129/http://www.tclf.org/pioneers/simonds.htm |archivedate=February 22, 2007 }}</ref> The social movement of [[World War II]] and the Pittsburgh [[Renaissance]] both greatly influenced Simonds' work. During this time Pittsburgh was in the need of deep restoration. The Simonds and Simonds Company became very popular, taking in many new commissions, the Mellon Square being one of the first and most important reconstructions of civic space.
In 1960 the company, now the Environmental Planning and Design Partnership, expanded their work away from Pittsburgh. The [[Chicago Botanic Garden]] became well known for its impact on landscape architecture.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagobotanic.org/info/index.php |title=About the Chicago Botanical Garden |publisher=Chicago Botanical Garden Organization |year=2007 |accessdate=2007-10-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071020040027/http://www.chicagobotanic.org/info/index.php |archivedate=2007-10-20 |df= }}</ref> The botanic garden was built from an unpleasant source of land in [[Glencoe, Illinois]]. "The site covers over 300 acres, featuring a series of island gardens with an administration and visitor education center on the largest island."<ref name=Smathers>{{cite web|url=http://www.uflib.ufl.edu/SPEC/exhibits/simonds.pdf| title=John Ormsbee Simonds Remembered| publisher=George Smathers Library| year=2006| accessdate=2007-10-28}}</ref> Simonds created a garden that incorporated an area for education of plants and actual touchable exhibits. Like the Mellon Square, the focus of creating relationships between human and plant can be seen within this design.
In the 1970s, [[Florida]] was in the process of creating new communities. During this time, Simonds changed his focus to large scale developments, allowing Florida's new communities to be options of work. [[Pelican Bay, Florida|Pelican Bay]], located in [[Naples, Florida]], became one of Simonds' great large-scale projects. He also established and developed the term PUD, [[Planned Unit Development]], within the bay community. The greatness of this design was the combination of nature and community with nothing overpowering the scene. The design involved the use of nature features, which enabled the area to preserve the [[ecology]] of the region.<ref name=Smathers/> Pelican Bay became widely appreciated and recognized after receiving the New Community Development Award for Excellence by the [[Urban Land Institute]].
Simonds took part in 500 projects and was a planner of 80 communities and 4 new towns. Some of his famous works include: *Pittsburgh Aviary - Conservatory [http://www.uflib.ufl.edu/spec/manuscript/guides/Simonds.htm] *[[Interstate 66]] in Virginia *Allegheny Commons [http://www.post-gazette.com/neigh_city/20011124commonscity1p1.asp]
== Significance to landscape architecture == Simonds moved the focus in landscape architecture from plants to the idea of plants and human relationship. He created a movement of change from landscape specialists to landscape [[environmentalists]], [[urban design]]ers, and [[regional planning|regional planners]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.uflib.ufl.edu/spec/manuscript/guides/Simonds.htm| title=A Guide to the John Ormsbee Simonds Collection.| author=Nemmers, John| page=3| publisher=George Smathers Libraries, University of Florida| year=2006| accessdate=2007-10-28}}</ref> The style in which he created was no longer just a design, but rather it became a place for people to experience. John Ormsbee Simonds will always have a great impact on Landscape Architecture and will continue to influence many landscape designs.
{{quote|One designs not places, or spaces, or things, one designs experiences.|John Ormsbee Simonds}}
==See also== *[[Landscape Architecture]] *[[Urban Planning]] *[[:Category:Landscape design history|Landscape design history]]
== References == {{reflist}}
Lowry, Patricia. "A John O. Simonds: Influential Landscape Architect." Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. 2005. University of Florida. 28 Oct 2007 http://www.iflaonline.org/news/john_simonds.html
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071020040027/http://www.chicagobotanic.org/info/index.php Chicago Botanic Garden] * [http://www.uflib.ufl.edu/SPEC/exhibits/simonds.pdf John Ormsbee Simonds Remembered]. Includes photographs of major designs. * [http://www.iflaonline.org/news/john_simonds.html Obituary: Prominent and Influential Landscape Architect] * [http://www.uflib.ufl.edu/spec/manuscript/guides/Simonds.htm A Guide to the John Ormsbee Simonds Collection] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070222114129/http://www.tclf.org/pioneers/simonds.htm Remembering John Simonds: Pioneer of American Landscape Design] * [http://www.asla.org/ American Society of Landscape Architects]
{{Authority control}}

[[Image:Florida hurricane (1950-1974) tracks.jpg|right|thumb|320px|Tracks of hurricanes over [[Florida]] from 1950 to 1974]] The '''list of Florida hurricanes from 1950 to 1974''' encompasses 85 Atlantic [[tropical cyclone|tropical]] or [[subtropical cyclone]]s that affected the [[U.S. state]] of [[Florida]]. Collectively, tropical cyclones in Florida during the time period resulted in about $7.04 billion (2017 USD) in damage, primarily from [[Hurricane Donna|Hurricanes Donna]] and [[Hurricane Dora|Dora]]. Additionally, tropical cyclones in Florida were directly responsible for 93 fatalities during the period, as well as responsible for 23 indirect deaths. Several tropical cyclones produced over 20 inches (500 mm) of rainfall in the state, including [[Hurricane Easy (1950)|Hurricane Easy]] which is the highest total during the time period. The [[1969 Atlantic hurricane season|1969 season]] was the year with the most tropical cyclones affecting the state, with a total of 8 systems. The [[1954 Atlantic hurricane season|1954]] and [[1967 Atlantic hurricane season|1967 seasons]] were the only years during the time period in which a storm did not affect the state.
The strongest hurricane to hit the state during the time period was [[Hurricane Donna]] in 1960, which was the 8th strongest hurricane on record to strike the United States.<ref name="damage 2006">{{cite web|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/pdf/NWS-TPC-5.pdf|title=THE DEADLIEST, COSTLIEST, AND MOST INTENSE UNITED STATES TROPICAL CYCLONES FROM 1851 TO 2006 (AND OTHER FREQUENTLY REQUESTED HURRICANE FACTS) |author1=Eric S. Blake |author2=Edward N. Rappaport |author3=Christopher W. Landsea |date=April 2007|accessdate=2007-04-11|page=26}}</ref> Additionally, [[Hurricane Easy (1950)|Hurricanes Easy]], [[Hurricane King|King]], [[Hurricane Isbell|Isbell]], and [[Hurricane Betsy|Betsy]] hit the state as [[tropical cyclone scales|major hurricanes]]. {{clear-right}} {{horizontal TOC|align=center|nonum=yes|limit=2}} ==1950â1959== [[Image:Easy_1950_rainfall.png|thumb|right|250 px|Hurricane Easy rainfall]] *August 31, 1950â [[Hurricane Baker (1950)|Hurricane Baker]] strikes near [[Mobile, Alabama]], with the eastern half of its circulation producing moderate damage from strong winds and two tornadoes across the [[Florida Panhandle]]. Heavy rainfall and winds also led to some crop damage.<ref name="1950mwr">{{cite web |author=Grady Norton |year=1951 |title=Hurricanes of 1951 |publisher=Weather Bureau Office |accessdate=2007-04-09 |url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1950.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Mu4tV7pK?url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1950.pdf |archivedate=2014-01-26 |df= }}</ref> *September 5, 1950â [[Hurricane Easy (1950)|Hurricane Easy]] moves ashore near [[Cedar Key, Florida|Cedar Key]] and later near [[Tampa Bay]] as a major hurricane after looping offshore. The hurricane causes locally heavy damage in a sparsely populated area, totaling $3.3 million (1950 USD, $29.5 million 2008 USD). Due to its erratic motion,<ref name="1950mwr"/> Easy drops heavy rainfall peaking at 38.7 inches (983 mm) in [[Yankeetown, Florida|Yankeetown]],<ref name="WPCMAX"/> which in turn causes 2 indirect deaths from electrocution.<ref name="1950mwr"/> *October 18, 1950â [[Hurricane King]] makes landfall on [[Miami]] as a major hurricane. Its hurricane-force winds blows out the windows of many buildings in downtown Miami, resulting in several injuries. Across the state, the storm causes 3 deaths and heavy damage totaling $27.8 million (1950 USD, $249 million 2008 USD), of which over half occurred in the Miami area.<ref name="1950mwr"/> *October 21, 1950â The threat of [[1950 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Love|Hurricane Love]] results in hurricane evacuations along the western coastline,<ref name="ap1021">{{cite web|author=Associated Press|date=1950-10-21|title=Florida Girds as New Storm Crosses Gulf|accessdate=2007-04-09|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=40559892&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160120043313/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=40559892&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-20|df=}}</ref> though dry air in the storm leads to very little effects after it hits near the mouth of the [[Steinhatchee River]].<ref name="ap1022">{{cite web|author=Associated Press|date=1950-10-22|title=Dry Air Takes Starch Out of Hurricane|accessdate=2007-04-09|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=55657230&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=6&currentPage=0|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160120043313/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=55657230&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=6&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-20|df=}}</ref> *May 18, 1951â The outer [[rainband]]s of [[Hurricane Able (1951)|Hurricane Able]] produce light rainfall and high seas along the eastern coastline.<ref name="up518">{{cite news|author=United Press|date=1951-05-18|title=Hurricane Hits Florida Coast|accessdate=2007-02-14|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=76606&firstvisit=true&currentResult=6&currentPage=0|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160120043313/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=76606&firstvisit=true&currentResult=6&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-20|df=}}</ref> *October 2, 1951â [[Hurricane How (1951)|Hurricane How]] hits [[Fort Myers, Florida|Fort Myers]], and produces flooding rains and winds of up to {{convert|60|mph|km/h}}. The storm results in $2 million in damage (1951 USD, $17 million 2008 USD), which is the only reported damage in the United States during the year.<ref name="1951mwr">{{cite web|author=Grady Norton|year=1952|title=Hurricanes of 1951|publisher=Weather Bureau Office|accessdate=2007-04-09|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/080/mwr-080-01-0001.pdf}}</ref> *February 3, 1952â An off-season tropical storm unofficially named the [[1952 Groundhog Day tropical storm|Groundhog Day tropical storm]] hits near [[Cape Sable]], producing gusty winds and moderate rainfall.<ref name="usa252">{{cite news|author=USAToday.com|title=Only February tropical storm hit Florida in 1952|accessdate=2007-04-08|url=https://www.usatoday.com/weather/hurricane/history/groundhog-day-storm.htm | work=USA Today | date=February 2, 2002}}</ref> *August 30, 1952â [[Hurricane Able (1952)|Hurricane Able]] recurves about 130 miles (210 km) east of the state, with the western portion of its circulation dropping {{convert|1.69|in|mm}} of precipitation in [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]].<ref name="able52">{{cite web|author=R.B. Ross|year=1952|title=Hurricane Able, 1952|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|url=http://ams.allenpress.com/perlserv/?request=res-loc&uri=urn%3Anoaa%3Apdf%3Afile%3Amwr-080-08-0138.pdf}}</ref> *June 6, 1953â [[Tropical Storm Alice (1953)|Tropical Storm Alice]] dissipates shortly after moving ashore near [[Panama City, Florida]], producing rainfall which breaks a dry spell in the state.<ref name="1953mwr">{{cite web|author=Grady Norton|year=1953|title=Hurricanes of 1953|publisher=Weather Bureau Office|accessdate=2007-04-07|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1953.pdf}}</ref> *August 29, 1953â An [[1953 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Three|unnamed tropical storm]] hits near [[Fort Myers, Florida|Fort Myers]]. While crossing the state it drops moderate precipitation, including {{convert|3.85|in|mm}} in [[Palm Beach, Florida|Palm Beach]].<ref name="up830">{{cite news|author=United Press International|date=1953-08-30|title=Weak Tropical Storm Spotted|accessdate=2007-04-07|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=16806051&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=4&currentPage=0|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160120043313/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=16806051&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=4&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-20|df=}}</ref> *September 20, 1953â The [[1953 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Seven|seventh storm]] of the season hits near [[Yankeetown, Florida|Yankeetown]], though its impact is unknown.{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} *September 26, 1953â [[Hurricane Florence (1953)|Hurricane Florence]] moves ashore near [[Destin, Florida|Destin]], causing rough surf and local flooding. Overall damage is minor, and the hurricane results in 3 injuries but no deaths.<ref name="927pcn">{{cite news|author=Panama City News Herald|date=1953-09-27|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=34847211&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|accessdate=2007-04-07|title=Subdued Florence Brushes City Area Leaving Little Damage, No Deaths|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160120043313/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=34847211&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-20|df=}}</ref> *Early October, 1953 â An [[1953 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Ten|unnamed tropical storm]] drops light rainfall across the state.{{Tropical Cyclone Rainfall in Florida}} *October 9, 1953â [[1953 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Hazel|Tropical Storm Hazel]] strikes [[Fort Myers, Florida|Fort Myers]], and produces gusty winds and additional rainfall to previously wet conditions. The passage of the storm causes flooding of low-lying areas and some rivers, with the upper region of the [[St. Johns River]] experiencing record-setting flooding.<ref name="1953mwr"/> *August 21, 1955â [[1955 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Brenda|Tropical Storm Brenda]] strikes southeastern [[Louisiana]], with its [[outer rainbands]] dropping precipitation along the western [[Florida Panhandle]].<ref name="1955mwr">{{cite web|author1=Gordon E. Dunn |author2=Walter R. Davis |author3=Paul L. Moore |year=1955 |title=Hurricanes of 1955 |publisher=American Meteorological Society |accessdate=2007-04-07 |url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1955.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629114604/http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1955.pdf |archivedate=2007-06-29 |df= }}</ref> *July 6, 1956â A [[1956 Atlantic hurricane season#July tropical depression|tropical depression]] moves ashore near [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]], resulting in light damage and moderate precipitation.<ref name="1956mwr"/> *September 24, 1956â [[Hurricane Flossy (1956)|Hurricane Flossy]] hits near [[Destin, Florida|Destin]] as a minimal hurricane, resulting in gusty winds and high tides reaching {{convert|7.4|ft|m}}. The storm causes light damage<ref name="1956mwr">{{cite web|author1=Gordon E. Dunn |author2=Walter R. Davis |author3=Paul L. Moore |year=1956|title=Hurricane Season of 1956|publisher=Weather Bureau Office|accessdate=2007-04-06|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/084/mwr-084-12-0436.pdf}}</ref> and 4 indirect deaths in near [[Tallahassee, Florida|Tallahassee]] from an airplane crash during an evacuation.<ref name="ap925">{{cite news|author=Associated Press|date=1856-09-25|title=Hurricane Flossy Diminishes Into Rainstorm Over Southern Georgia|accessdate=2007-04-06|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=37780406&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160120043313/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=37780406&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-20|df=}}</ref> *October 15, 1956â A [[1956 Atlantic hurricane season#Quasi-tropical storm|quasi-tropical storm]] makes landfall near [[Miami]] and drops moderate to heavy rainfall. The storm causes $3 million in damage (1956 USD, $24 million 2008 USD) and 2 deaths from drowning.<ref name="1956mwr"/> *November 1956â Rough surf from [[Hurricane Greta (1956)|Hurricane Greta]] causes about $1.1 million in damage (1956 USD, $8.7 million 2008 USD) along the eastern coastline, primarily near [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]].<ref name="1956mwr"/> *June 8, 1957â The [[1957 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm One|first storm]] of the season hits near [[Tallahassee, Florida|Tallahassee]], dropping heavy rainfall of over {{convert|19|in|mm}} in [[Suwannee County, Florida|Suwannee County]] which forces hundreds of families to evacuate. Offshore, rough waves capsize a boat and kill 5, with minimal onshore damage.<ref name="1957mwr">{{cite web|author=Paul L. Moore |year=1957 |title=The Hurricane Season of 1957 |publisher=Weather Bureau Office |accessdate=2007-04-05 |url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1957.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130217210552/http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1957.pdf |archivedate=2013-02-17 |df= }}</ref> *September 8, 1957â [[1957 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Debbie|Tropical Storm Debbie]] moves ashore along the [[Florida Panhandle]], causing flooding, rainfall, and 4 indirect deaths.<ref name="1957mwr"/> *September 4, 1958â [[Hurricane Ella (1958)|Tropical Storm Ella]] emerges into the [[Gulf of Mexico]] after crossing [[Cuba]], with its outer [[Rainband#Tropical cyclones|rainbands]] producing gale force wind gusts in the [[Florida Keys]]. The winds uproots a few trees, though damage is minor.<ref name="miaherell">{{cite web|author=Denne Petitclerc|year=1958|title=Ella Staggers Out of Cuba|work=Miami Herald|accessdate=2007-04-05|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1958/ella/news/new0904b.gif}}</ref> *June 18, 1959â An unnamed [[1959 Escuminac Hurricane|tropical depression]] hits near [[Tampa Bay]] and spawns at least two tornadoes, one of which causes heavy damage and many injuries in [[Miami]]. High tides and moderate rainfall caused damage, as well, and monetary damage across the state totals $1.5 million (1959 USD, $11.1 million 2008 USD).<ref name="1959mwr"/> *October 8, 1959â [[Tropical Storm Irene (1959)|Tropical Storm Irene]] hits near [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]] and causes a peak wind gust of {{convert|55|mph|km/h}} as well as a [[storm tide]] reaching {{convert|4.4|ft|m}} above normal. Damage is minor.<ref name="1959mwr"/> *October 18, 1959â [[1959 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Judith|Tropical Storm Judith]] strikes near [[Fort Myers, Florida|Fort Myers]], producing light to moderate rainfall peaking at {{convert|7.9|in|mm}} in [[Miles City, Florida|Miles City]].<ref name="WPCMAX"/> Damage from the storm is minor, with no deaths and only one injury attributed to Judith.<ref name="1959mwr">{{cite web|author=Gordon E. Dunn|year=1959|title=The Hurricane Season of 1959|publisher=Weather Bureau Office|accessdate=2007-04-05|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/087/mwr-087-12-0441.pdf}}</ref> ââ
==1960â1969== [[Image:Biscayneblvd1960donna flooding.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Damage from [[Hurricane Donna]] in [[Miami]]]] *July 29, 1960â [[Tropical Storm Brenda (1960)|Tropical Storm Brenda]] hits near [[Yankeetown, Florida|Yankeetown]], producing locally heavy rainfall which reaches over 13 inches (330 mm) near [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]]. The rainfall causes flooding and a few indirect traffic deaths, and damage in the state totals $5 million (1960 USD, $36 million 2008 USD).<ref name="1960mwr">{{cite web|author=Gordon E. Dunn|year=1961|title=The Hurricane Season of 1960|publisher=Weather Bureau Office|accessdate=2007-04-05|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/089/mwr-089-03-0099.pdf}}</ref> *September 10, 1960â [[Hurricane Donna]] strikes near [[Cape Sable]] after crossing the [[Florida Keys]], and after briefly moving emerging into the [[Gulf of Mexico]] makes its final landfall near [[Fort Myers, Florida|Fort Myers]]. It leaves a path of destruction across the entire peninsula, including destroying 30% of the state's grapefruit crop and leveling over half of the [[mangrove]] trees in the [[Everglades]].<ref name="1960mwr"/> The passage of the hurricane results in 2,156 destroyed homes, 3,903 severely damaged houses, and 281 boats destroyed or left with major damage.<ref name="miamidonna">{{cite web|author=Miami Herald|year=1960|title=Here's What Donna Did|accessdate=2007-04-05|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1960/donna/news/miami.gif}}</ref> Throughout the state, Donna causes over $300 million in damage (1960 USD, $2.19 billion 2008 USD) and 13 direct deaths.<ref name="1960mwr"/> *September 15, 1960â [[Hurricane Ethel (1960)|Tropical Storm Ethel]] strikes [[Mississippi]] after rapidly weakening from a strong hurricane, and causes light winds and rainfall across western Florida. Damage totals about $250,000 (1960 USD, $1.8 million 2008 USD), primarily from crop damage.<ref name="ethel60">{{cite web|author=Cecil E. Mahaffey|year=1960|title=Supplemental Report on Hurricane Ethel|publisher=Pensacola, Florida Weather Bureau Office|accessdate=2007-04-05|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1960/ethel/preloc/pshpns01.gif}}</ref> *September 23, 1960â [[1960 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Florence|Tropical Depression Florence]] strikes near [[Chokoloskee, Florida|Chokoloskee]], and after turning westward near [[Vero Beach, Florida|Vero Beach]] emerges into the [[Gulf of Mexico]] before making a final landfall near [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]]. The storm drops moderate amounts of rainfall, causing localized but minor amounts of damage.<ref name="1960mwr"/> *September 11, 1961â [[Hurricane Carla]] strikes [[Texas]], with its outer [[Rainband#Tropical cyclones|rainbands]] dropping light amounts of precipitation across Florida.<ref name="carlarain">{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2005|title=Rainfall Summary for Hurricane Carla|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2007-04-05|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/carla1961.html}}</ref> *October 29, 1961 â The interaction between [[Hurricane Hattie]] and a ridge to its north produced squally winds of around 30 mph (50 km/h) across Florida.<ref name="disc5">{{cite web|author=Dunn and Moore|date=October 1961|title=Advisory 9 for Hurricane Hattie|publisher=Miami, Florida Weather Bureau|accessdate=2009-04-13|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1961/hattie/prenhc/prelim06.gif|format=GIF}}</ref> *August 26, 1962â A [[1962 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Alma|tropical depression]] which later becomes Hurricane Alma brushes the southeastern portion of the state, dropping 3.6 inches (91 mm) of rain at [[Fort Drum, Florida|Fort Drum]].<ref name="HURDAT"/><ref name="Florida Rain"/> *October, 1963â Rough surf from [[Hurricane Flora]] kills one in [[Miami]].<ref name="florpre">{{cite web|author=National Weather Bureau|year=1963|title=Preliminary Summary on Hurricane Flora|accessdate=2007-04-05|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1963/flora/prenhc/draftb1.gif}}</ref> *October 21, 1963â [[Hurricane Ginny]] passes about 50 miles (80 km) east of the state before turning northeastward, producing gusty winds, light rainfall, and minor damage.<ref name="1963mwr">{{cite web|author=Gordon E. Dunn|year=1964|title=The Hurricane Season of 1963|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau Office|accessdate=2007-04-05|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/092/mwr-092-03-0128.pdf}}</ref> *June 6, 1964â A [[1964 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm One|tropical depression]] hits near [[Yankeetown, Florida|Yankeetown]] and exits near [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]]. The depression produces thunderstorm activity and hail storms across the northern portion of the state, causing about $1 million in damage (1964 USD, $7 million 2008 USD).<ref name="1964mwr"/> [[Image:Cleo1964AtlMIArdar.png|thumb|right|250px|Radar image of [[Hurricane Cleo]] at landfall in Miami]] *August 27, 1964â [[Hurricane Cleo]] strikes near [[Miami]] with winds of about 105 mph (170 km/h), the first hurricane to hit the area in 14 years. Strong winds from the hurricane down many trees and power lines, with moderate to heavy building and crop damage reported near the coast. Rainfall reaches 6.8 inches (173 mm) in Miami, with [[storm tide]]s peaking at 5.5 feet (1.7 m) in [[Pompano Beach, Florida|Pompano Beach]]. Damage in the state amounts to $125 million (1964 USD, $870 million 2008 USD); no deaths are reported in the state.<ref name="1964mwr"/> *September 10, 1964â [[Hurricane Dora]] makes landfall as a weakening [[Category 2 hurricane]] near [[Jacksonville Beach, Florida|Jacksonville]], the first hurricane in an extended period of time to strike the area. Dora produces moderate to heavy amounts of precipitation which peaks at 23.73 inches (603 mm) in [[Mayo, Florida|Mayo]], causing flooding damage and killing one from drowning. Wind gusts peak at 125 mph (200 km/h) near [[St. Augustine, Florida|St. Augustine]], causing massive utility failures and heavy damage to buildings. Two [[United States Navy|Navy]] personnel die when their evacuating plane crashed upon takeoff. Damage totaled about $220 million (1964 USD, $1.53 billion 2008 USD).<ref name="1964mwr"/> *September 20, 1964â [[Hurricane Gladys (1964)|Hurricane Gladys]] produces rough surf along the eastern Florida coastline.<ref name="upi920">{{cite web|author=United Press International|year=1964|title=Hurricane Moving on Georgia|publisher=Oakland Tribune|accessdate=2007-03-28|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=31648866&firstvisit=true&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160120043313/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=31648866&firstvisit=true&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-20|df=}}</ref> *October 5, 1964â The [[extratropical cyclone|extratropical]] remnant of [[Hurricane Hilda]] enters the [[Florida Panhandle]], dropping moderately heavy rainfall and producing high tides.<ref name="1964mwr"/> One person drowns while surfing near [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]].<ref name="hildapensrepo">{{cite web|author=Pensacola National Weather Service|year=1964|title=Effects of Hurricane Hilda on the Florida Panhandle|accessdate=2007-03-28|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1964/hilda/preloc/pshpns.gif}}</ref> *October 14, 1964â [[Hurricane Isbell]] makes landfall near [[Everglades, Florida|Everglades]] and drops moderate amounts of precipitation peaking at 9.46 inches (240 mm) in [[West Palm Beach, Florida|West Palm Beach]].{{Tropical Cyclone Point Maxima}} The hurricane spawns at least 11 tornadoes and injured at least 50, mostly minor. Throughout the state, the hurricane kills three, of which one indirectly, and causes over $5 million (1964 USD, $35 million 2008 USD) in crop damage.<ref name="1964mwr">{{cite web|author=Gordon E. Dunn|year=1965|title=Hurricanes of 1964|publisher=United States Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-03-28|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/093/mwr-093-03-0175.pdf}}</ref> *June 15, 1965â An unnamed tropical storm hits near [[Panama City, Florida|Panama City]], producing high tides and moderate rainfall peaking at 5.99 inches (152 mm) in [[Tallahassee, Florida|Tallahassee]]. Damage from the storm is minor, and no deaths or injuries are reported.<ref name="ts165">{{cite web|author=L.E. Hughes|year=1965|title=Report on Tropical Storm One (1965)|publisher=Tallahassee National Weather Service|accessdate=2007-02-09|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1965/ts01/preloc/tlh0728.gif}}</ref> [[Image:Hurricane Betsy eye.jpg|thumb|200px|right|A view from the interior of Hurricane Betsy's [[eye (cyclone)|eye]], taken by [[Hurricane hunters]] before its Florida landfall]] *September 8, 1965â [[Hurricane Betsy]] passes through the [[Florida Keys]] as a major hurricane, producing moderate rainfall reaching 11.8 inches (300 mm) at [[Plantation Key, Florida|Plantation Key]] and wind gusts reaching an estimated peak of 160 mph (255 km/h) in [[North Key Largo, Florida|North Key Largo]]. The rainfall provided relief to a water shortage in the [[Everglades]], while strong waves and high tides causes considerable flooding in coastal and low-lying areas in the southeastern portion of the state. The passage of Betsy results in 4 deaths and $139.3 million in damage (1965 USD, $953 million 2008 USD) in the state.<ref name="1965mwr">{{cite web|author=Arnold Sugg|year=1966|title=The Hurricane Season of 1966|publisher=United States Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-02-09|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/094/mwr-094-03-0183.pdf}}</ref> Betsy would enter the Gulf of Mexico and cause much greater devastation in southeastern [[Louisiana]], where the storm caused 76 deaths and over $1 billion in damage. *September 30, 1965â [[Tropical Storm Debbie (1965)|Tropical Storm Debbie]] dissipates off of the coast of [[Mississippi]] and drops 3â5 inches (75â125 mm) of precipitation across the northern region of the state.<ref name="1965mwr"/> *June 9, 1966â [[Hurricane Alma (1966)|Hurricane Alma]] makes landfall near [[Apalachicola, Florida|Apalachicola]] as a [[Category 2 hurricane]] after paralleling the western coastline as a major hurricane. Rainfall peaked at 7.7 inches (196 mm) in [[Miami]], while tides reached {{convert|10|ft|m}} above normal. The maximum sustained winds peaked at {{convert|125|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} as it passed Key West. Alma causes $10 million in damage (1966 USD, $66 million 2008 USD), 2 direct deaths from drowning, and 4 indirect deaths.<ref name="1966mwr">{{cite web|author=Arnold Sugg|year=1967|title=The Hurricane Season of 1966|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2007-02-08|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1966.pdf}}</ref> *June 30, 1966â A [[Tropical Depression Two (1966)|tropical depression]] forms in the western Caribbean Sea and moves on a track similar to Alma. The center passed near [[Key Largo, Florida|Key Largo]], producing two tornadoes, one of which destroyed two aircraft at [[Palm Beach International Airport]], as well as moderate to heavy rainfall totaling nearly 10 inches (250 mm) at [[Everglades City, Florida|Everglades City]] and [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]].<ref name="1966mwr"/> The combination of Alma and this tropical depression brought 21.37 inches/542.8 mm to [[Miami]], which established a new June rainfall record for that location.<ref>A. James Wagner. [http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/094/mwr-094-09-0587.pdf The Weather and Circulation of June 1966.] Retrieved on 2007-04-24.</ref> *July 24, 1966â The [[Tropical Depression Seven (1966)|precursor tropical low]] to a tropical depression crosses the northern portion of the state; its effects are minimal.<ref name="1966mwr"/> *October 4, 1966â [[Hurricane Inez]] passes through the [[Florida Keys]], resulting in 3 deaths and $5 million in damage (1966 USD, $33 million 2008 USD).<ref name="1966mwr"/> Rainfall in the state peaks at 4.8 inches (122 mm) at [[Kendall, Florida|Kendall]],<ref name="WPCMAX"/> while offshore the hurricane results in 45 casualties in the [[Florida Straits]].<ref name="1966mwr"/> *June 4, 1968â [[Hurricane Abby (1968)|Tropical Storm Abby]] moves ashore near [[Punta Gorda, Florida|Punta Gorda]], spawning 3 small tornadoes and producing up to 14.2 inches (361 mm) of precipitation at [[Cocoa, Florida|Cocoa]]. The rainfall is beneficial and ends a severe, persistent drought in the state. The storm causes six indirect deaths in the state.<ref name="1968mwr">{{cite web|author1=Arnold Sugg |author2=Paul Hebert |lastauthoramp=yes|year=1969|title=The Atlantic Hurricane Season of 1968|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2007-02-06|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/097/mwr-097-03-0225.pdf}}</ref> *June 18, 1968â The precursor tropical depression to [[1968 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Brenda|Hurricane Brenda]] passes across the eastern portion of the state, dropping moderate precipitation peaking at 8.61 inches (219 mm) in [[Homestead, Florida|Homestead]]. No damage is reported.<ref name="WPCMAX"/><ref name="1968mwr"/> *July 5, 1968â A tropical depression strikes the [[Florida Panhandle]] and quickly dissipates, though its impact is unknown.<ref name="1968tw">{{cite web|author1=R. H. Simpson |author2=Neil Frank |author3=David Shideler |author4=H.M. Johnson |last-author-amp=yes |year=1969|title=Atlantic tropical disturbances of 1968|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2007-02-06|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/097/mwr-097-03-0240.pdf}}</ref> *August 10, 1968â The precursor tropical depression to [[Hurricane Dolly (1968)|Hurricane Dolly]] moves through the eastern portion of the state, producing gusty winds though no known damage.<ref name="1968mwr"/> *August 28, 1968â A tropical depression stalls along the western coastline near [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]] before turning to the northeast and crossing the state.<ref name="1968tw"/> It drops heavy rainfall, including 15 inches (381 mm) in [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]], resulting in extensive localized flooding. The depression also spawns a tornado near [[Daytona Beach, Florida|Daytona Beach]] which destroys a motel and several houses.<ref name="1968mwr"/> [[File:Tropical Depression Twenty-Nine 1969 rainfall.gif|thumb|right|250 px|September 20â25, 1969 Tropical Depression Rainfall]] *September 26, 1968â A tropical depression crosses the southern portion of the state, though its impact is unknown.<ref name="1968tw"/> *October 19, 1968â [[Hurricane Gladys (1968)|Hurricane Gladys]] makes landfall just north of Tampa Bay, producing moderate rainfall and two tornadoes while crossing the state. Damage totals $6.7 million (1968 USD, $42 million 2008 USD), primarily due to structural damage.<ref name="1968mwr"/> *June 9, 1969â A [[1969 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Depression Seven|tropical depression]] dissipates shortly after passing through the [[Florida Keys]]. Its effects are unknown.<ref name="1969tw">{{cite web|author=Neil L. Frank|year=1970|title=Atlantic Tropical Systems of 1969|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2007-02-04|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/098/mwr-098-04-0307.pdf}}</ref> *August 18, 1969â [[Hurricane Camille]] strikes southern [[Mississippi]] as a [[List of Category 5 Atlantic hurricanes|Category 5 hurricane]], with its large wind field producing a 71 mph (114 km/h) wind gust and 3.55 inches (90 mm) of rain in [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]].<ref name="1969mwr">{{Cite web|author1=R. H. Simpson |author2=Arnold Sugg |lastauthoramp=yes|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2007-02-04|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/098/mwr-098-04-0293.pdf|title=The Atlantic Hurricane Season of 1969|year=1970}}</ref> The hurricane causes minor crop damage to pecan trees and corn stalks.<ref name="camille08">{{cite web|author=National Hurricane Center|year=1969|title=Hurricane Camille Preliminary Report (Page 8)|accessdate=2007-02-04|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1969-prelim/camille/prelim08.gif}}</ref> *August 29, 1969â A tropical depression makes landfall on the east-central portion of the state, though its impact is unknown.<ref name="1969tw"/> *September 7, 1969â The precursor tropical depression to [[Hurricane Gerda]] passes over the southeastern portion of the state before turning to the northeast.<ref name="1969mwr"/> Its rainfall impact was minimal, as less than three inches (76 mm) of rain fell across the Sunshine State.<ref name="Florida Rain"/> *September 21, 1969â A tropical depression moves ashore along the western [[Florida Panhandle]], before stalling. It becomes the wettest known tropical cyclone for the eastern Florida panhandle, when 23.40 inches (594 mm) falls at [[Havana, Florida|Havana]].<ref name="wpc1969">{{cite book|author=Roth, David M|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/tdoflatesep1969.html|title=September 20â25, 1969 Tropical Depression|accessdate=2012-06-13|author2=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|publisher=United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Weather Service|year=2012}}</ref> *October 1, 1969â [[1969 Atlantic hurricane season#Subtropical Storm One|Subtropical Depression One]] hits the western [[Florida Panhandle]]. Its effects, if any, are unknown.<ref name="1969mwr"/> *October 2, 1969â [[1969 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Jenny|Tropical Storm Jenny]] makes landfall near [[Fort Myers, Florida|Fort Myers]], crosses the state, and approaches the [[Atlantic Ocean]] near [[Cape Canaveral]] before turning to the west-southwest and exiting into the [[Gulf of Mexico]] near [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]]. The storm produces heavy rainfall of 5â8 inches (127â203 mm) across the central region of the state.<ref name="1969mwr"/> *October 21, 1969â [[1969 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Laurie|Hurricane Laurie]] attains a peak strength of 105 mph (170 km/h) while moving eastward in the [[Gulf of Mexico]]. Its threat prompts officials to issue a gale warning from the [[Florida Keys]] to [[Fort Myers, Florida|Fort Myers]], though Laurie turns to the southwest and does not impact the state.<ref name="1969mwr"/>
==1970â1974==
===1970=== [[Image:Tropical Depression Alma (1970).JPG|right|thumb|250px|Remnants of Tropical Depression Alma]] *May 25, 1970â [[Hurricane Alma (1970)|Tropical Depression Alma]] makes landfall near [[Yankeetown, Florida|Yankeetown]], producing moderate rainfall of 5â10 inches (127â254 mm) which ends a persistent drought in the southern portion of the state.<ref name="alma70pre">{{cite web|author=PJH|author2=National Hurricane Center|year=1970|title=Hurricane Alma 1970|type=Preliminary Report|page=3|publisher=United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Weather Service|accessdate=2012-06-13|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1970-prelim/alma}}</ref> *July 22, 1970â [[Tropical Storm Becky (1970)|Tropical Storm Becky]] hits [[Apalachicola, Florida|Apachicola]], producing moderate rainfall peaking at over 8 inches (203 mm) in [[Tallahassee, Florida|Tallahassee]] which floods 104 houses and injures two. The storm also spawns a tornado which destroys a house and severely damages three others in [[Panacea, Florida|Panacea]].<ref name="becky70pre">{{cite web|author=National Hurricane Center|year=1970|title=Tropical Storm Becky Preliminary Report|accessdate=2007-02-03|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1970-prelim/becky/prelim03.gif}}</ref> *August 6, 1970â A tropical depression moves ashore near [[Cape Canaveral]], though its effects, if any, are unknown.<ref name="1970tw">{{cite web|author=Neil L. Frank|year=1971|title=Atlantic Tropical Systems of 1970|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2007-02-03|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/099/mwr-099-04-0281.pdf}}</ref> *September 13, 1970â The precursor tropical depression to [[Tropical Storm Felice]] passes through the [[Florida Keys]], dropping beneficial rainfall to the southern portion of the state.<ref name="1970mwr">{{cite web|author1=R. H. Simpson |author2=Joseph Pelisser |lastauthoramp=yes |year=1971 |title=Atlantic Hurricane Season of 1970 |publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=2007-02-03 |url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1970.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629062304/http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1970.pdf |archivedate=2011-06-29 |df= }}</ref> *September 27, 1970â [[Tropical Storm Greta (1970)|Tropical Storm Greta]] passes through the [[Florida Keys]] as a weakening tropical cyclone, producing tropical storm force wind gusts but no reported damage.<ref name="1970mwr"/>
===1971=== *August 10, 1971â [[Hurricane Beth|A tropical depression]] which later becomes Hurricane Beth forms near [[Miami]] and subsequently tracks northeastward. Its effects in the state, if any, are unknown.<ref name="1971mwr"/> *August 13, 1971â A tropical depression strikes [[Fort Myers, Florida|Fort Myers]], turns to the northwest into the [[Gulf of Mexico]], intensifies as it turned to the northeast, and moves ashore near [[Steinhatchee, Florida|Steinhatchee]]. The depression produces hurricane-force wind gusts at [[Cedar Key, Florida|Cedar Key]] and drops rainfall of over 8 inches (203 mm), resulting in some coastal flooding.<ref name="1971mwr">{{cite web|author1=R. H. Simpson |author2=John R. Hope |lastauthoramp=yes|year=1972|title=Atlantic Hurricane Season of 1971|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2007-02-03|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1971.pdf}}</ref> *August 29, 1971â A tropical depression moves across the southern portion of the state, though its effects are unknown.<ref name="1971mwr"/> *September 1, 1971â The mid-level precursor disturbance to [[Hurricane Fern]] moves across the central portion of the state, dropping moderate precipitation which reaches over 5 inches (127 mm) near [[Miami]].<ref name="fern71rain">{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2006|title=Rainfall Summary for Hurricane Fern (1971)|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2007-02-03|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/fern1971.html}}</ref> *September 16, 1971â [[Hurricane Edith (1971)|Hurricane Edith]] hits southern [[Louisiana]], producing light rainfall and a tornado near [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]].<ref name="1971mwr"/> *October 13, 1971â A tropical depression moves ashore near [[Apalachicola, Florida|Apalachicola]], though its effects are unknown.<ref name="1971mwr"/>
===1972=== *May 28, 1972â [[Subtropical Storm Alpha (1972)|Subtropical Storm Alpha]] makes landfall near [[Brunswick, Georgia]] and turns southwestward across northern Florida, dropping light rainfall across its path but causing no damage.<ref name="up529">{{cite news|author=United Press International|date=1972-05-29|title=Cyclone Sweeps Through Panhandle|accessdate=2007-02-03|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=35262110&firstvisit=true&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160120043313/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=35262110&firstvisit=true&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-20|df=}}</ref> [[Image:Agnes-tornado-track.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Plot of tornadoes by F-scale and severe thunderstorms of the Agnes outbreak]] *June 19, 1972â [[Hurricane Agnes]] strikes [[Panama City, Florida|Panama City]] with minimal hurricane-force winds and a storm surge peaking at 7 feet (2.1 m) in [[Cedar Key, Florida|Cedar Key]]. Agnes produces moderate rainfall throughout the state, amounting to a maximum of 8.97 inches (228 mm) in [[Naples, Florida|Naples]].<ref name="1972mwr">{{cite web|author1=P.H. Simpson |author2=Paul Hebert |lastauthoramp=yes|year=1973|title=Atlantic Hurricane Season of 1972|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2007-02-03|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1972.pdf}}</ref> The hurricane spawns 28 tornadoes in the state which destroy 15 houses and 217 trailers.<ref name="agnestornado">{{cite web|author1=Bartlett C. Hagemeyer |author2=Scott M. Spratt |lastauthoramp=yes|year=2002 |title=Thirty Years after Hurricane Agnes: The Forgotten Florida Tornado Disaster |publisher=Melbourne, Florida National Weather Service |accessdate=2007-02-03 |url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/mlb/PDFs/agnes30.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081016213739/http://www.srh.noaa.gov/mlb/PDFs/agnes30.pdf |archivedate=October 16, 2008 }}</ref> Throughout the state, Agnes causes $8.2 million in damage (1972 USD, $42 million 2008 USD) and nine deaths, seven of which are from the tornadoes.<ref name="agnes09">{{cite web|author=National Hurricane Center|year=1972|title=U.S. Deaths and Damage Attributed to Agnes|accessdate=2007-02-03|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1972-prelim/agnes/prelim09.gif}}</ref> *September 5, 1972â The tropical depression that later becomes [[1972 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Dawn|Hurricane Dawn]] briefly passes over southeastern Florida before turning northeastward.<ref name="1972mwr"/>
===1973=== *June 7, 1973â A tropical depression develops over the southeastern portion of the state, and briefly enters the [[Gulf of Mexico]] before hitting [[St. Marks, Florida|St. Marks]]. Its effects are unknown.<ref name="1973tw">{{cite web|author1=Neil L. Frank|author2=Paul Hebert|lastauthoramp=yes|year=1974|title=Atlantic Tropical Systems of 1973|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2007-02-02|url=http://ams.allenpress.com/archive/1520-0493/102/4/pdf/i1520-0493-102-4-290.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20070204131524/http://ams.allenpress.com/archive/1520-0493/102/4/pdf/i1520-0493-102-4-290.pdf|archivedate=2007-02-04|df=}} </ref> *June 23, 1973â An area of disturbed weather forms into a tropical depression over the northern portion of the state and subsequently tracks to the northeast.<ref name="1973tw"/> *September 3, 1973â A tropical depression intensifies into [[Tropical Storm Delia (1973)|Tropical Storm Delia]] over the open [[Gulf of Mexico]], producing light rain across Florida before striking [[Texas]].<ref name="deliarain">{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2006|title=Rainfall Summary for Tropical Storm Delia|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2007-02-02|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/delia1973.html}}</ref> *September 25, 1973â [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]] is struck by a tropical depression, though its effects, if any, are unknown.<ref name="1973tw"/>
===1974=== *June 25, 1974â The combination of [[Subtropical Storm One (1974)|Subtropical Storm One]], which struck [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]], and a tropical depression to its southwest, produce slightly above normal tides and heavy rainfall reaching 20 inches (508 mm) near Tampa Bay. The passage of these systems cause three fatalities from drowning and $10 million in damage (1974 USD, $44 million 2008 USD) from tidal and rainfall flooding.<ref name="1974mwr">{{cite web|author=John R. Hope|year=1975|title=Atlantic Hurricane Season of 1974|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2007-02-02|url=http://ams.allenpress.com/archive/1520-0493/103/4/pdf/i1520-0493-103-4-285.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20070202212557/http://ams.allenpress.com/archive/1520-0493/103/4/pdf/i1520-0493-103-4-285.pdf|archivedate=2007-02-02|df=}} </ref> *September 8, 1974â [[Hurricane Carmen]] makes landfall on southern [[Louisiana]], with its outer [[rainband]]s producing precipitation across the state that reaches over 10 inches (254 mm) in the extreme northwestern portion of the state.<ref name="carmenrain">{{Cite web|author=David Roth|year=2005|title=Rainfall Summary for Hurricane Carmen|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2007-02-02|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/carmen1974.html}}</ref> *September 27, 1974â A tropical depression dissipates shortly after moving ashore near [[Cedar Key, Florida|Cedar Key]] and causes no known effects.<ref name="1974tw">{{cite web|author=Neil L. Frank|year=1975|title=Atlantic Tropical Systems of 1974|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2007-02-02|url=http://ams.allenpress.com/archive/1520-0493/103/4/pdf/i1520-0493-103-4-294.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20070204152612/http://ams.allenpress.com/archive/1520-0493/103/4/pdf/i1520-0493-103-4-294.pdf|archivedate=2007-02-04|df=}} </ref> *October 7, 1974â [[1974 Atlantic hurricane season#Subtropical Storm Four|Subtropical Storm Four]] passes just offshore the eastern coastline and produces some beach erosion and localized flooding from rainfall peaking at 14 inches (356 mm) in [[Boca Raton, Florida|Boca Raton]].<ref name="1974mwr"/>
==Monthly statistics== {{bar graph|float=center | title = Number of recorded storms affecting Florida | data_max = 30 | label_type = Month | data_type = Number of storms | label1 = January | data1 = | label2 = February | data2 = 1 | label3 = March | data3 = 0 | label4 = April | data4 = 0 | label5 = May | data5 = 3 | label6 = June | data6 = 14 | label7 = July | data7 = 5 | label8 = August | data8 = 14 | label9 = September | data9 = 26 | label10 = October | data10 = 20 | label11 = November | data11 = 1 | label12 = December | data12 = }}
==Deadly storms== The following is a list of hurricanes with known deaths in the state.

Number of deaths |- | [[Hurricane Inez|Inez]] || 1966 || 48 (45 [[Straits of Florida|offshore]]) |- | [[Hurricane Donna|Donna]] || 1960 || 13 |- | [[Hurricane Agnes|Agnes]] || 1972 || 9 |- | [[1957 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm One|Unnamed]] || 1957 || 5 |- | [[Hurricane Betsy|Betsy]] || 1965 || 4 |- | [[Hurricane King|King]] || 1950 || 3 |- | [[Subtropical Storm One (1974)|Unnamed]] || 1974 || 3 |- | [[Hurricane Alma (1966)|Alma]] || 1966 || 2 (4 indirect) |- | [[Hurricane Isbell|Isbell]] || 1964 || 2 (1 indirect) |- | [[1956 Atlantic hurricane season#Quasi-tropical storm|Unnamed]] || 1956 || 2 |- | [[Hurricane Dora|Dora]] || 1964 || 1 (2 indirect) |- | [[Hurricane Flora|Flora]] || 1963 || 1 |- | [[Hurricane Hilda|Hilda]] || 1964 || 1 |- | [[Hurricane Abby (1968)|Abby]] || 1968 || 0 (6 indirect) |- | [[Hurricane Flossy (1956)|Flossy]] || 1956 || 0 (4 indirect) |- | [[1957 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Debbie|Debbie]] || 1957 || 0 (4 indirect) |- | [[Hurricane Easy (1950)|Easy]] || 1950 || 0 (2 indirect) |- | [[Hurricane Dora|Dora]] || 1964 || 0 (2 indirect) |- | [[Tropical Storm Brenda (1960)|Brenda]] || 1960 || 0 (''few'' indirect) |} </center>
