page.title: List of medicinal plants of the American West

revision.comment: /* External links */ Removed an invalid link.
revision.text:
Many plants that grow in the [[American West]] have use in [[traditional medicine|traditional]] and [[herbalism|herbal medicine]].
[[Image:Eriogonum fasciculatum 5.jpg|thumb|right|''[[Eriogonum fasciculatum]], used in treatment of headaches and diarrhea.'']] [[File:Taraxacum plant.jpg|thumb|right|[[Taraxacum officinale|Dandelion]] (''Taraxacum officinale'') contains a large number of pharmacologically active compounds, and has been used for centuries as an effective laxative and diuretic, and as a treatment for [[bile]] or [[liver]] problems.<ref name=Schutz>{{Cite journal | last1 = Schutz | first1 = K. | last2 = Carle | first2 = R. | last3 = Schieber | first3 = A. | doi = 10.1016/j.jep.2006.07.021 | title = TaraxacumâA review on its phytochemical and pharmacological profile | journal = Journal of Ethnopharmacology | volume = 107 | issue = 3 | pages = 313â323 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16950583 | pmc = }}</ref>]]
==List of medicinal plants== * [[Salvia mellifera|Black sage]], (''Salvia mellifera''), can be used against pain.{{medcn|date=November 2014}} A strong [[sun tea]] of the [[leaves]] and [[Plant stem|stem]]s of the plant can be rubbed on the painful area or used to soak one's feet. The plant contains [[diterpenoid]]s, such as [[aethiopinone]] and [[ursolic acid]], that are pain relievers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://wildfoodplants.com/file_download/26 |title=Palliative Care Among Chumash People |format=PDF |publisher=Wild Food Plants |accessdate=2007-07-14 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071006174719/http://wildfoodplants.com/file_download/26 |archivedate=2007-10-06 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
* [[Broadleaf plantain]] (''Plantago major'') is one of the most abundant and widely distributed medicinal crops in the world. A [[poultice]] of the leaves can be applied to wounds, stings, and sores in order to facilitate healing and prevent infection.{{medcn|date=November 2014}} The active chemical constituents are [[aucubin]] (an anti-microbial agent), [[allantoin]] (which stimulates cellular growth and tissue regeneration), and [[mucilage]] (which reduces pain and discomfort).{{medcn|date=November 2014}} Plantain has astringent properties, and a tea made from the leaves can be ingested to treat diarrhea and soothe raw internal membranes.{{medcn|date=November 2014}} * [[California bay]] (''Umbellularia californica'') leaves were used by the [[Tongva people]] to treat pain.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.runajambi.net/tongva/california%20bay%20laurel.htm | title=Takape Kakaaka | work=Tongva Medicinal Plants | accessdate=2007-07-14 }}</ref>
* [[California poppy]] (''Eschscholzia californica'') was chewed by California Indians to treat toothache and to decrease milk production in nursing mothers anti-[[galactogogue]].<ref>{{cite book | author=Strike, Sandra | title=Ethnobotany of the California Indians. Vol. 2. | chapter=Aboriginal Uses of California's Indigenous Plants | publisher=Champaign: Koeltz Scientific Books |year=1994 | isbn=1-878762-51-6 }}</ref>
* [[Ephedra]] spp. is used as a [[diuretic]], as a treatment for [[urinary tract infections]], for [[asthma]], and as [[stimulant]] due to the presence of [[ephedrine]] and other compounds.{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} The sale of [[dietary supplement]]s containing ephedra has been banned in the United States due to the risk of [[serious adverse event]]s or death.<ref>[http://www.fda.gov/oc/initiatives/ephedra/february2004/ Sales of Supplements Containing Ephedrine Alkaloids (Ephedra) Prohibited] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070210003231/http://www.fda.gov/oc/initiatives/ephedra/february2004/ |date=2007-02-10 }}. From the U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]]. Accessed September 12, 2007.</ref> * [[Horsetail]] or ''Scouring Rush'' (''Equisetum spp.'') is used as a [[diuretic]] because of it contains high concentrations of [[oxalic acid]] and [[calcium oxalate]] and therefore can also be a throat irritant if brewed improperly.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid=4094471 | title=Diuretic activity of Mexican equisetum | journal=J Ethnopharmacol |date=NovemberâDecember 1985 | volume=14 | issue=2â3 | pages=269â272 |author1=PÃ©rez GutiÃ©rrez RM |author2=Laguna GY |author3=Walkowski A. | doi=10.1016/0378-8741(85)90093-5 }}</ref>
* [[Matilija poppy]], (''Romneya coulteri'') is applied [[topical]]ly to treat sunburn.<ref name="herbs">{{cite web |url = http://hort-devel-nwrec.hort.oregonstate.edu/herbs.html |title = Herbs and Spices |work = Commercial Vegetable Production Guides |publisher = Oregon State University |date = April 2, 2002 |accessdate = 2007-07-14 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070706040348/http://hort-devel-nwrec.hort.oregonstate.edu/herbs.html |archivedate = July 6, 2007 |df = }}</ref>
* [[Willow]] ''Salix spp.'' used to treat headache and as an [[antipyretic]] due to the content of [[salicylic acid]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Mackowiak PA |title=Brief history of antipyretic therapy |journal=Clin. Infect. Dis. |volume=31 |issue= Suppl 5 |pages=S154âS156 |date=October 2000 |pmid=11113017 |doi= 10.1086/317510|url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/resolve?CID000192}}</ref> * [[Yarrow]] (''Achillea millefolium'') is used for various ailments including cramps, fevers, and toothache.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/med-aro/factsheets/YARROW.html | publisher=Purdue Center for New Crops | date=December 2, 1997 | accessdate=2007-07-14 | title=Yarrow | work=Factsheets }}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of plants used in herbalism]] *[[Traditional medicine]] *[[Herbalism]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading == There are several books about western medicinal plants:
* {{cite book | author=Moerman, Daniel E. | title=Native American Ethnobotany | publisher=Timber Press, Portland |year=2000 | isbn=0-88192-453-9 }} A comprehensive collection of many plants with descriptions of their uses. * {{cite book | author=Strike, Sandra S. | title=Ethnobotany of the California Indians. Volume 2 | chapter=Aboriginal uses of California's Indigenous Plants | publisher=Koeltz Scientific Books USA, Champaign |year=1994 | isbn=1-878762-51-6 }} Very thorough discussion of California medicinal plants. * {{cite book | author=George R. Mead | title=The Ethnobotany of the California Indians: A Compendium of the Plants, Their Users, and Their Uses | publisher=University of Northern Colorado Press, Greeley |year=1972 }} A partial list of plants used in the west. * {{cite book |author1=S. Foster |author2=C. Hobbs |lastauthoramp=yes | title=The Peterson Field Guide Series A Field Guide to Western Medicinal Plants and Herbs | publisher=Houghton Mifflin Co, New York | year=2002 | isbn=0-395-83807-X }} A field guide with photographs of each plant and descriptions of their uses. * {{cite book |author1=C. Garcia |author2=J.D. Adams |lastauthoramp=yes | title=Healing with Medicinal Plants of the West - Cultural and Scientific Basis for their Use | publisher=Abedus Press, La Crescenta |year=2005 | isbn=0-9763091-0-6 }} Gives the Chumash Indian and scientific basis for use of many plants, along with color photographs of each plant. Cecilia Garcia is a [[Chumash (tribe)|Chumash]] healer. * {{cite book | author=Lowell J. Bean and [[Katherine Siva Saubel]] | title=Temalpakh: Cahuilla Indian Knowledge and Usage of Plants | publisher=Malki Museum Press, Morongo Indian Reservation |year=1972 }} A discussion of [[Cahuilla]] Indian plants and their uses. Saubel is a Cahuilla Indian.
==External links== * [http://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/med-aro/ A Guide to Medicinal and Aromatic Plants]
[[Category:Flora of the Western United States|*]] [[Category:Medicinal plants of North America|*]] [[Category:Lists of flora of the United States]] [[Category:Lists of flora of California]] [[Category:Plants used in traditional Native American medicine|*â¢]] [[Category:Indigenous peoples of California topics]] [[Category:Western United States]]

page.title: List of mountain passes in Wyoming (K-Y)

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Wyoming transport-related lists to [[:Category:Wyoming transportation-related lists]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
[[File:KingmanPassGoldenGateYNP1921.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Kingman Pass, Park County, Wyoming 1921]] {{geoGroupTemplate}} {{See also|List of mountain passes in Wyoming (A-J)}} There are at least '''250 named [[mountain pass]]es in [[Wyoming]]'''.
'''Wyoming''' {{IPAc-en|audio=en-us-Wyoming.ogg|w|aÉª|Ë|oÊ|m|Éª|Å}} is a [[U.S. state|state]] in the mountain region of the [[Western United States]]. Wyoming is the [[List of U.S. states and territories by area|10th most extensive]], but the [[List of U.S. states and territories by population|least populous]] and the [[List of U.S. states and territories by population density|2nd least densely populated]] of the [[50 United States]]. The western two thirds of the state is covered mostly with the mountain ranges and rangelands in the foothills of the [[Rocky Mountains|Eastern Rocky Mountains]], while the eastern third of the state is high elevation prairie known as the [[High Plains (United States)|High Plains]].
* [[Kagevah Pass]], [[Sublette County, Wyoming]], {{coord|42|55|30|N|109|21|22|W|display=inline |name=Kagevah Pass}}, el. {{convert|11283|ft|m}}<ref>{{cite gnis |id=1600673|name=Kagevah Pass}}</ref> * {{short description|Oceanic landforms and topographic elements.}} [[File:Oceanic divisions.svg|350px|thumb|right|Depiction of the [[abyssal zone]] in relation to other major [[oceanic zone]]s.]]
This is a '''list of submarine topographical features''', oceanic [[landform]]s and [[topographic]] elements.
==Abyssal plain== An [[abyssal plain]] is an underwater [[plain]] on the deep [[ocean floor]], usually found at depths between {{convert|3000|m|sp=us}} and {{convert|6000|m|sp=us}}. Lying generally between the foot of a [[Continental shelf#Topography|continental rise]] and a [[mid-ocean ridge]], abyssal plains are among the flattest, smoothest and least explored regions on Earth.<ref name=Weaver>{{cite book |title = Geology and Geochemistry of Abyssal Plains |author1 = P.P.E. Weaver |author2 = J. Thomson |author3 = P. M. Hunter |year = 1987 |publisher = Blackwell Scientific Publications |location = Oxford |page = x |isbn = 0-632-01744-9 |url = http://sp.lyellcollection.org/cgi/issue_pdf/frontmatter_pdf/31/1.pdf |accessdate = 27 June 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101224060317/http://sp.lyellcollection.org/cgi/issue_pdf/frontmatter_pdf/31/1.pdf |archivedate = 24 December 2010 |df = }}</ref> Abyssal plains are key geologic elements of [[oceanic basin]]s (the other elements being an elevated mid-ocean ridge and flanking [[abyssal hill]]s). In addition to these elements, ''active'' oceanic basins (those that are associated with a moving [[Plate tectonics|plate tectonic]] boundary) also typically include an [[oceanic trench]] and a [[subduction|subduction zone]]. Abyssal plains cover more than 33% of the ocean floor (about 23% of Earthâs surface),<ref name="Harris, P.T. 2014">{{cite journal | author = Harris P.T., MacMillan-Lawler M., Rupp J., Baker E.K. | year = 2014 | title = Geomorphology of the oceans | url = | journal = Marine Geology | volume = 352 | issue = | pages = 4â24 | doi=10.1016/j.margeo.2014.01.011| bibcode = 2014MGeol.352....4H}}</ref> but they are poorly preserved in the [[Geologic record|sedimentary record]] because they tend to be consumed by the subduction process.<ref name=Weaver/><ref name=CRS2008>{{cite journal |author1=Craig R. Smith |author2=Fabio C. De Leo |author3=Angelo F. Bernardino |author4=Andrew K. Sweetman |author5=Pedro Martinez Arbizu |last-author-amp=yes |title=Abyssal food limitation, ecosystem structure and climate change |journal=Trends in Ecology and Evolution |volume=23 |pages=518â528 |year=2008 |url=http://cmbc.ucsd.edu/Students/Current_Students/SIO277/Smith%20et%20al.%20TREE%202008.pdf |pmid=18584909 |issue=9 |doi=10.1016/j.tree.2008.05.002 |accessdate=27 June 2010 |ref=harv}}</ref><ref name=Vino1997>{{cite journal |author=N.G. Vinogradova |title=Zoogeography of the Abyssal and Hadal Zones |journal=Advances in Marine Biology |volume=32 |pages=325â387 |year=1997 |doi=10.1016/S0065-2881(08)60019-X |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S006528810860019X |ref=harv |series=Advances in Marine Biology |isbn=978-0-12-026132-1}}</ref>
The abyssal plain is formed when the lower [[oceanic crust]] is melted and forced upwards by the [[asthenosphere]] layer of the upper [[Mantle (geology)|mantle]]. As this [[basalt]]ic material reaches the surface at mid-ocean ridges, it forms new oceanic crust. Abyssal plains result from the blanketing of an originally uneven surface of oceanic crust by fine-grained [[sediment]]s, mainly [[clay]] and [[silt]]. Much of this sediment is deposited from [[turbidity current]]s that have been channeled from the [[continental margin]]s along [[submarine canyon]]s down into deeper water. The remainder of the sediment is composed chiefly of [[pelagic sediments]].
Use of a continuously recording [[Fishfinder|fathometer]] enabled Tolstoy & Ewing in the summer of 1947 to identify and describe the first abyssal plain.<ref name=Weaver/><ref name=Tolstoy1949/> This plain, located to the south of [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]], is now known as the [[Sohm Abyssal Plain]].<ref name=Tolstoy1949>{{cite journal |author1=Ivan Tolstoy |author2=Maurice Ewing |lastauthoramp=yes|title=North Atlantic hydrography and the mid-Atlantic Ridge |journal=Geological Society of America Bulletin |volume=60 |issue=10 |pages=1527â40 |date=October 1949 |url=http://bulletin.geoscienceworld.org/cgi/content/abstract/60/10/1527 |ref=harv |doi=10.1130/0016-7606(1949)60[1527:NAHATM]2.0.CO;2 |bibcode = 1949GSAB...60.1527T }}</ref> Following this discovery many other examples were found in all the oceans.<ref name=Heezen1951>{{cite journal |author=Bruce C. Heezen, Maurice Ewing and D.B. Ericson |title=Submarine topography in the North Atlantic |journal=Geological Society of America Bulletin |volume=62 |issue=12 |pages=1407â1417 |date=December 1951 |doi=10.1130/0016-7606(1951)62[1407:STITNA]2.0.CO;2 |url=http://bulletin.geoscienceworld.org/cgi/content/abstract/62/12/1407 |accessdate=29 June 2010 |ref=harv |issn=0016-7606 |bibcode = 1951GSAB...62.1407H }}</ref><ref name=Heezen1954>{{cite journal |author=Bruce C. ==Oceanic trenches== [[File:Marianatrenchmap.png|300px|thumb|right|Location of the [[Challenger Deep]] in the [[Mariana Trench]]]] [[Oceanic trench]]es are long, narrow [[topography|topographic]] depressions of the [[seabed]]. They are the deepest parts of the ocean floor, and they define one of the most important natural boundaries on the Earth's solid surface: the one between two [[Lithosphere|lithospheric]] plates. Trenches are a distinctive morphological feature of [[Plate boundaries#Types of plate boundaries|plate boundaries]]. Trenches are found in all oceans with the exception of the Arctic Ocean and they are most common in the North and South Pacific Oceans.<ref name="Harris, P.T. 2014"/>
There are three types of lithospheric plate boundaries: 1.) [[Divergent boundary|divergent]] (where lithosphere and oceanic crust is created at mid-ocean ridges), 2.) [[Convergent boundary|convergent]] (where one lithospheric plate sinks beneath another and returns to the mantle), and 3.) [[Transform fault|transform]] (where two lithospheric plates slide past each other).
An oceanic trench is a type of convergent boundary at which two oceanic lithospheric slabs meet; the older (and therefore denser) of these slabs flexes and subducts beneath the other slab. Oceanic lithosphere moves into trenches at a global rate of about a tenth of a square meter per second. Trenches are generally parallel to a [[High island|volcanic]] [[island arc]], and about 200 km from a [[volcanic arc]]. Oceanic trenches typically extend 3 to 4 km (1.9 to 2.5 mi) below the level of the surrounding oceanic floor. The greatest ocean depth to be sounded is in the [[Challenger Deep]] of the [[Mariana Trench]], at a depth of 10,911 m (35,798 ft) below sea level.

==Oceanic plateau== An '''[[oceanic plateau]]''' is a large, relatively flat submarine region that rises well above the level of the ambient seabed.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/424535/oceanic-plateau oceanic plateau]. (2008). In EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica. Retrieved June 27, 2010, from EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica Online.</ref> While many oceanic plateaus are composed of [[continental crust]], and often form a step interrupting the [[continental margin|continental slope]], some plateaus are undersea remnants of [[large igneous province]]s. Continental crust has the highest amount of [[silicon]] (such rock is called [[felsic]]). Oceanic crust has a smaller amount of silicon ([[mafic]] rock).
The anomalous [[volcanism]] associated with the formation of oceanic plateaux at the time of the [[Cenomanian]]-[[Turonian]] boundary (90.4 [[Megaannum#SI prefix multipliers|million years]]) ago may have been responsible for the environmental disturbances that occurred at that time. The physical manifestations of this were elevated atmospheric and oceanic temperatures, a significant sea-level transgression, and a period of widespread [[anoxic event|anoxia]], leading to the extinction of 26% of all [[Genus|genera]].<ref name=Kerr1998>{{cite journal |author=Andrew C. Kerr |title=Oceanic plateau formation: A cause of mass extinction and black shale deposition around the Cenomanian-Turonian boundary? |journal=Journal of the Geological Society |volume=155 |issue=4 |pages=619â626 |date=July 1998 |doi=10.1144/gsjgs.155.4.0619 |issn=0016-7649 |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3721/is_199807/ai_n8805326/ |accessdate=27 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111105054118/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3721/is_199807/ai_n8805326/ |archivedate=5 November 2011 |df= |bibcode=1998JGSoc.155..619K }}</ref> These eruptions would also have resulted in the emission of large quantities of [[carbon dioxide]] into the atmosphere, leading to [[global warming]]. Additionally, the emission of [[sulfur monoxide]], [[hydrogen sulfide]], [[carbon monoxide]], and [[halogen]]s into the oceans would have made seawater more [[acid]]ic resulting in the dissolution of [[carbonate]], and further release of {{CO2}}. This [[runaway greenhouse effect]] was probably put into reverse by the decline of the anomalous volcanic activity and by increased {{CO2}}-driven productivity in oceanic surface waters, leading to increased [[organic carbon]] burial, black [[shale]] deposition, anoxia and [[Extinction event|mass extinction]] in the ocean basins.<ref name=Kerr1998/> [[File:Zealandia-Continent map en.svg|thumb|300px|right|Map of the [[Zealandia (continent)|Zealandia]] [[Continental fragment|microcontinent]], showing [[Alpine Fault]], [[Bounty Trough]], [[Campbell Plateau]], [[Challenger Plateau]], [[Chatham Rise]], [[Havre Trough]], [[Hikurangi Plateau]], [[Kermadec Trench]], [[Lord Howe Rise]], [[Louisville Ridge]], [[New Caledonia Basin]], [[Norfolk Ridge]], [[South Fiji Basin]], [[South West Pacific Basin]], and [[Tasman Basin]].]]

==Mid-ocean ridges== A [[mid-ocean ridge]] is a general term for an [[underwater]] [[mountain range|mountain system]] that consists of various mountain ranges (chains), typically having a valley known as a [[rift]] running along its spine, formed by [[plate tectonics]]. This type of oceanic ridge is characteristic of what is known as an oceanic spreading center, which is responsible for [[seafloor spreading]].

*{{cite journal |author1=Schwabe E. |author2=Bohn J.M. |author3=Engl W. |author4=Linse K. |author5=SchrÃ¶dl M. |title=Rich and rare - first insights into species diversity and abundance of Antarctic abyssal Gastropoda (Mollusca) |journal=Deep-Sea Research Part II |volume=54 |issue=16â17 |pages=1831â1847 |year=2007 |doi=10.1016/j.dsr2.2007.07.010 |url= |bibcode=2007DSR....54.1831S}}
*{{cite journal |author1=Sebastian S. |author2=Raes M. |author3=De Mesel I. |author4=Vanreusel A. |title=Comparison of the nematode fauna from the Weddell Sea Abyssal Plain with two North Atlantic abyssal sites |journal=Deep-Sea Research Part II |volume=54 |issue=16â17 |pages=1727â1736 |year=2007 |doi=10.1016/j.dsr2.2007.07.004 |url= |bibcode=2007DSR....54.1727S}}

{{About|the mineral|lightweight, slow-flying aeroplanes|Microlight}} {{No footnotes|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox mineral | name = Microlite | boxwidth = | boxbgcolor = | image = Microlite-bem-42a.jpg | imagesize = 260px | alt = | caption = | category = [[Oxide minerals]] | formula = (Na,Ca)<sub>2</sub>Ta<sub>2</sub>O<sub>6</sub>(O,OH,F) | strunz = 04.DH.15 | dana = | symmetry = | unit cell = | molweight = | color = | colour = | habit = | system = | twinning = | cleavage = | fracture = | tenacity = | mohs = | luster = | streak = | diaphaneity = | gravity = | density = | polish = | opticalprop = | refractive = | birefringence = | pleochroism = | 2V = | dispersion = | extinction = | length fast/slow = | fluorescence = | absorption = | melt = | fusibility = | diagnostic = | solubility = | impurities = | alteration = | other = | prop1 = | prop1text = | references = }} '''Microlite''' was once{{when|date=April 2018}} known as a pale-yellow, reddish-brown, or black [[Cubic (crystal system)|isometric]] [[mineral]] composed of [[sodium]] [[calcium]] [[tantalum]] [[oxide]] with a small amount of [[fluorine]] (Na,Ca)<sub>2</sub>Ta<sub>2</sub>O<sub>6</sub>(O,OH,F). Today{{when|date=April 2018}} it is a name of a group of oxide minerals of a similar stoichiometry having tantalum prevailing over titanium and niobium. The microlite group belongs to a large [[pyrochlore]] supergroup that occurs in [[pegmatite]]s and constitutes an [[ore]] of tantalum. It has a [[Mohs hardness]] of 5.5 and a variable [[specific gravity]] of 4.2 to 6.4. It occurs as disseminated microscopic subtranslucent to opaque octahedral [[crystal]]s with a [[refractive index]] of 2.0 to 2.2. Microlite is also called djalmaite, but both names are now obsolete.
"Microlite" occurs as a primary mineral in lithium-bearing granite pegmatites, and in [[Miarolitic cavity|miarolitic cavities]] in granites. Association minerals include: [[albite]], [[lepidolite]], [[topaz]], [[beryl]], [[tourmaline]], [[spessartine]], [[tantalite]] and [[fluorite]].
"Microlite" was first described in 1835 for an occurrence on the Island of Uto, State of Stockholm, [[Sweden]]. A [[Type locality (geology)|type locality]] is the Clark Ledges pegmatite, Chesterfield, [[Hampshire County, Massachusetts]]. The name is from Greek ''mikros'' for "small" and ''lithos'' for "stone."
==References== *Palache, C., H. Berman, and C. Frondel (1944) ''Danaâs system of mineralogy'', (7th edition), v. I, 748â757 *[http://webmineral.com/data/Microlite.shtml Webmineral data] *[http://www.mindat.org/min-2705.html Mindat with location data] *[http://rruff.geo.arizona.edu/doclib/hom/microlite.pdf Mineral data publishing PDF]
{{Commons category}}
[[Category:Oxide minerals]] [[Category:Tantalum minerals]] [[Category:Cubic minerals]]

The Canadian Mineralogist, 48(3), 673-698.[http://doi/:%2010.3749/canmin.48.3.673 doi: 10.3749/canmin.48.3.673]{{dead link|date=February 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} *Andrade, M. B., Atencio, D., Menezes Filho, L. A., & Ellena, J. (2011). CANADIAN MINERALOGIST, 49(5), 1338-1338.[http://%20doi:10.3749/canmin.49.2.615 doi:10.3749/canmin.49.2.615]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}

{{Infobox rockunit | name = Nacientes del BiobÃ­o Formation | image = | caption = | type = [[Geologic formation]] | period = Kimmeridgian | age = [[Pliensbachian]]â[[Kimmeridgian]] | prilithology = [[Basalt]]ic [[lava]], [[sandstone]], [[mudstone]], [[limestone]] | otherlithology = [[Tuff]], [[breccia|volcaniclastic breccia]], [[conglomerate (geology)|conglomerate]] | namedfor = [[BÃ­o BÃ­o River]] | namedby = Manuel SuÃ¡rez and Carlos Emparan (1997) | region = [[NeuquÃ©n Province]]
[[AraucanÃ­a Region]] | country = {{ARG}}
{{CHL}} | coordinates = | unitof = | subunits = Lonquimay
LolÃ©n-Pacunto
Icalma | underlies = [[Vizcacha-Cumilao Complex]] | overlies = Unknown | thickness = more than {{convert|2450|m|ft|abbr=on}} | extent = | area = | map = | map_caption = }} '''Nacientes del BiobÃ­o Formation''' ({{lang-es|FormaciÃ³n Nacientes del BiobÃ­o}}) is a [[geological formation]] that [[outcrop|crops out]] near the uppermost reaches of [[BÃ­o BÃ­o River]], in south-central [[Chile]], and nearby areas of [[Argentina]]. The formation is made up of [[basalt]] and [[pyroclastic rock]]s and marine sedimentary rocks, such as [[sandstone]] and [[mudstone]]. Some less abundant sedimentary lithologies are [[conglomerate (geology)|conglomerate]], [[volcaniclastic|volcaniclastic sedimentary rock]]. The formation is intruded by ''Grupo PlutÃ³nico GalletuÃ©'' which is of [[Late Jurassic]] to [[Late Cretaceous]] age. Further north in Chile the formation is similar to Nacientes del Teno Formation while in Argentina it is similar to [[Los Molles Formation]] and [[Lotena Formation]].SuÃ¡rez, M. and Emparan, C. (1997). Hoja CuracautÃ­n, Carta geolÃ³gica de Chile. ==Subunits== SuÃ¡rez and Emparan have identified three interdigitating members of the formation the older one being Miembro Icalma, the youngest one being Miembro Lonquimay and Miembro LolÃ©n-Pacunto being in-between. The ages of the formation as well of that of the members have been established through fossil [[ammonite]] findings.{{cite journal |last=De la Cruz |first=Rita |last2=SuÃ¡rez |first2=Manuel |date=1997 |title=El JurÃ¡sico de la cuenca de NeuquÃ©n en Lonquimay, Chile: FormaciÃ³n Nacientes del BiobÃ­o (38-39Â°8) |url= |journal=[[Andean Geology|Revista geolÃ³gica de Chile]] |volume=24 |issue=1 |pages=3â24 |doi= |access-date=|language=Spanish }} Miembro Icalma contains [[basalt]]ic [[pillow lava]] and other features indicative of deep marine eruptions. Volcanic rocks, including basalt, belong to the [[Tholeiitic magma series|tholeiitic]] and [[calc-alkaline magma series|calc-alkaline]] series showing [[geochemistry|geochemical]] affinities with [[island arc]] [[magma]]s. Miembro Icalma do also contains marine fossils of ''[[Harpoceratinae]]'' and ''[[Atacamiceras]]'' in its sedimentary strata that indicate a [[Pliensbachian]] to [[Toarcian|Mid-Toarcian]] age for the sub-unit. Miembro LolÃ©n-Pacunto is made up chiefly of mudstone and sandstone. Miembro Lonquimay stands out for containing limestone and [[paleochannel]]s filled with sandstone. ==Interpretation== The formation is interpreted as indicative of a [[Jurassic]] [[marine regression]] showing a successive shallowing of deep marine environments (pillow lavas, [[turbidite]]s) to shallow marine environments (limestone) and culminating with an upper region displaying a continental environment (paleochannels). Tectonically the formation is assumed to have deposited either in the westernmost fringes of [[NeuquÃ©n Basin]] or in an [[intra-arc basin]]. In both cases the formation must have been deposited very close to a [[volcanic arc]] active in the Jurassic. == References == {{reflist}} {{Geology of Chile}} [[Category:Geologic formations of Chile]] [[Category:Geologic formations of Argentina]] [[Category:Geology of AraucanÃ­a Region]] [[Category:Geology of NeuquÃ©n Province]] [[Category:Early Jurassic South America]] [[Category:Middle Jurassic South America]] [[Category:Late Jurassic South America]] [[Category:Jurassic Argentina]] [[Category:Jurassic Chile]] [[Category:Tuff formations]]

revision.text:
{{about|the admittance matrix in electrical engineering|the graph theoretic admittance matrix|Laplacian matrix}}
In [[power engineering]], '''nodal admittance matrix''' (or just '''admittance matrix''') or '''Y Matrix''' or '''Ybus''' is an ''N x N'' [[matrix (mathematics)|matrix]] describing a power system with ''N'' [[Bus (power engineering)|buses]]. It represents the nodal [[admittance]] of the buses in a power system. In realistic systems which contain thousands of buses, the Y matrix is quite sparse. Each bus in a real power system is usually connected to only a few other buses through the [[electric power transmission|transmission line]]s. The Y Matrix is also one of the data requirements needed to formulate a [[power flow study]].
== Context == [[Power engineering|Electric power transmission]] needs optimization in order to determine the necessary real and reactive power flows in a system for a given set of loads, as well as the voltages and currents in the system. Power flow studies are used not only to analyze current power flow situations, but also to plan ahead for anticipated disturbances to the system, such as the loss of a transmission line to maintenance and repairs. The power flow study would determine whether or not the system could continue functioning properly without the transmission line. Only [[computer simulation]] allows the complex handling required in power flow analysis because in most realistic situations the system is very complex and extensive and would be impractical to solve by hand. The Y Matrix is a tool in that domain. It provides a method of systematically reducing a complex system to a matrix than can be solved by a computer program. The equations used to construct the Y matrix come from the application of Kirchhoffâs current law and Kirchhoffâs voltage law to a circuit with steady-state sinusoidal operation. These laws give us that the sum of currents entering a node in the circuit is zero, and the sum of voltages around a closed loop starting and ending at a node is also zero. These principles are applied to all the nodes in a power flow system and thereby determine the elements of the admittance matrix, which represents the admittance relationships between nodes, which then determine the voltages, currents and power flows in the system.
== Construction ==
Starting from the [[One-line diagram|single line diagram]] of a power system, there are three main steps before writing the equations that form the <math>Y</math> Matrix. First, the single line diagram is converted to an impedance diagram. Next, all voltage sources are converted to their equivalent current source representations. From here, the impedance diagram is then converted to an admittance diagram. Following these three steps, the admittance matrix can be created in a straightforward manner: For an admittance diagram with <math>N</math> buses, the admittance between the bus in consideration, ''k'', and another bus, ''i'', connected to ''k'', can be described by <math>y_{ik} = g_{ik} + j b_{ik}</math>. The term <math>y_k</math> should be introduced here; this term accounts for the admittance of linear loads connected to bus <math>k</math> as well as the admittance-to-ground at bus <math>k</math>. The general mathematical expression follows:
:<math> Y_{ij} = \begin{cases} y_{i} + \sum_{k=1, 2, \ldots, N \atop k \neq i} {y_{ik}}, & \mbox{if} \quad i = j \\ -y_{ij}, & \mbox{if} \quad i \neq j \end{cases} </math>
It is important to note that <math>y_{ki}</math> is non-zero only where a physical connection exists between two buses.<ref>{{cite web|last1=McCalley|first1=James|title=The Power Flow Equations|url=http://home.eng.iastate.edu/~jdm/ee458_2011/PowerFlowEquations.pdf|website=Iowa State Engineering}}</ref> This consideration is not seen in the following example because each node is connected to both of the other nodes. Each <math>y_{ki}</math> defines one element of the <math>N\times{N}</math> matrix. From the general case where N is greater than 2, it is desirable to solve these equations as a system, namely through matrix algebra. The general matrix appears as follows: The nodal admittance matrix form: <math> Y = \begin{bmatrix} Y_{11} & Y_{12} & \cdots & Y_{1n} \\ Y_{21} & Y_{22} & \cdots & Y_{2n} \\ \cdots & \cdots & \cdots & \cdots \\ Y_{n1} & Y_{n2} & \cdots & Y_{nn} \end{bmatrix} </math> [[File:3 bus network.jpg|400px|thumbnail|The admittance diagram of a three bus network.]]
Once the admittance matrix has been formed, the admittance matrix can be input to solve the matrix form of Ohm's Law--the equation <math>Y*V=I</math>. In this instance <math>V</math> is an <math>N\times{1}</math> vector of the voltage at each node and <math>I</math> is the <math>N\times{1}</math> vector of corresponding currents. In matrix form, Ohm's Law is as follows: :<math> \begin{pmatrix} Y_{11} & Y_{12} & \cdots & Y_{1N} \\ Y_{21} & Y_{22} & \cdots & Y_{2N} \\ \vdots & \ddots & \cdots & \vdots \\ Y_{NN} & Y_{N2} & \cdots & Y_{NN} \\ \end{pmatrix} *
\begin{pmatrix} V_1 \\ V_2 \\ \vdots \\ V_N \\ \end{pmatrix} =
\begin{pmatrix} I_1 \\ I_2 \\ \vdots \\ I_N \\ \end{pmatrix}
</math> To illustrate this process with the admittance matrix of the three bus network in the figure would be:
:<math> Y = \begin{pmatrix} y_{1} + y_{12} + y_{13} & - y_{12} & - y_{13} \\ -y_{12} & y_{2} + y_{12} + y_{23} & - y_{23} \\ -y_{13} & - y_{23} & y_{3} + y_{13} + y_{23} \\ \end{pmatrix} </math> The Y Matrix diagonal elements <math>Y_{11}, Y_{22}, ..., Y_{nn}</math> are called the ''self-admittances'' at the nodes, and each equals the sum of all the admittances terminating on the node identified by the repeated subscripts. The other admittances are the ''mutual admittances'' of the nodes, and each equals the negative of the sum of all admittances connected directly between the nodes identified by the double subscripts. The admittance matrix <math>Y</math> is typically a [[symmetric matrix]] as <math>y_{mn} = y_{nm}</math>. However, extensions of the line model and models of other components such as transformers may make <math>Y</math> asymmetrical.<ref>{{cite book |first1=John |last1=Grainger |year=1994 |title=Power System Analysis |publisher=McGraw-Hill Science/Engineering/Math |isbn=978-0070612938 |url=https://www.amazon.com/Power-System-Analysis-John-Grainger/dp/0070612935}}</ref>
For small transmission systems of about less than 10 nodes or buses, the Y matrix can be calculated manually. But for a realistic system with relatively large number of nodes or buses, say 1000 nodes, a computer program for computing Y is more practical to use.
[[File:Node Network.gif|thumb|Node Network Courtesy of scialert.net]] To help motivate the importance of using a system of equations in matrix form, see the adjacent figure. Not only does it become impractical to calculate the current vector <math>V</math> by hand, it becomes necessary to use computational power to form the admittance matrix itself.
Example:<ref>{{cite book|last1=Grainger|first1=John|title=Power System Analysis|date=1994|publisher=McGraw-Hill Science/Engineering/Math|isbn=978-0070612938|pages=240-241|edition=1}}</ref>
[[File:Two Node Power Flow Diagram.png|thumb|left|Two node power flow diagram courtesy of Grainger and Stevenson]] To take a look at a generalizable <math>2\times2</math> matrix, consider the figure of the two-node network. By [[Kirchhoff's_circuit_laws#Kirchhoff.27s_current_law_.28KCL.29|Kirchhoff's Current Law]], it can be shown that :<math> \begin{pmatrix} I_m \\ I_n \\ \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ \end{pmatrix} * I_a </math> since there are no other currents entering or exiting nodes <math>m</math> or <math>n</math>. The voltage drop across the line can be expressed as :<math> V_a = \begin{pmatrix} 1 * -1 \\ \end{pmatrix}*\begin{pmatrix} V_m \\ V_n \\ \end{pmatrix} </math>. Next, use [[Ohm's Law]] with admittance instead of impedance. Using substitution to get :<math> \begin{pmatrix} Y_a & -Y_a \\ -Y_a & Y_a \end{pmatrix}*\begin{pmatrix} V_m \\ V_n \\ \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} I_m \\ I_n \\ \end{pmatrix} </math>. To reintroduce some generality, <math> Y_{11} = Y_{mm}, Y_{21} = Y_{nm},Y_{12} = Y_{mn},</math> and <math> Y_{22} = Y_{nn} </math>. Thus, this example can be taken as a first step in understanding how to generally construct an <math>NxN</math> matrix by hand.
==See also== *[[Admittance parameters]] *[[Zbus]]
== References ==
{{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060206073952/http://www.jcmiras.net/jcm/item/73/ A C/C++ Program and Source Code for Computing Ybus and Zbus Matrices]

{{for|the motorcycle|Honda Pacific Coast}} [[File:Acapulco.jpg|thumb|250px|Coast of the [[Pacific Ocean]]]]
A country's '''Pacific coast''' is the part of its [[coast]] bordering the [[Pacific Ocean]].
==Geography== ===Americas=== Countries on the western side of the [[Americas]] have a Pacific coast as their western border. * [[Geography of Canada]] * [[Geography of Chile]] * [[Geography of Colombia]] * [[Geography of Costa Rica]] * [[Geography of Ecuador]] * [[Geography of El Salvador]] * [[Geography of Guatemala]] * [[Geography of Honduras]] * [[Pacific Coast of Mexico]] * [[Geography of Nicaragua]] * [[Geography of Panama]] * [[Geography of Peru]] * [[West Coast of the United States]]
===Asia=== Countries on the [[East Asia|eastern]] and [[Maritime Southeast Asia|southeastern]] sides of [[Asia]] have a Pacific coast as part (or all) of their border. * {{C|Pacific Coast of Russia}} * [[Geography of Japan]] * [[Geography of Indonesia]] * [[Geography of North Korea]] * [[Geography of South Korea]] * [[Geography of the People's Republic of China|Geography of China]] * [[Geography of the Philippines]] * [[Geography of Malaysia]] * [[Geography of Singapore]] * [[Geography of Brunei]] * [[Geography of Taiwan]] * [[Geography of Vietnam]] * [[Geography of Cambodia]] * [[Geography of East Timor]] * [[Geography of Thailand]]
===Oceania=== Countries in [[Oceania]] may have a Pacific coast anywhere, including their entire border. * [[Geography of Australia]] * [[Geography of French Polynesia]] ([[France]]) * [[Geography of New Zealand]] * [[Geography of Papua New Guinea]]
==External links== * {{Commons category-inline|Coasts of the Pacific Ocean}}
[[Category:Coasts of the Pacific Ocean| 01]] [[Category:Pacific Ocean|C]] [[Category:Coasts]] [[Category:Coastal geography]]

revision.text:
[[File:La Pincoya.jpg|thumb|Pincoya statue]] The '''Pincoya''' is, according to local mythology, a female "water spirit" of the [[ChiloÃ© Island|Chilot]]an Seas. The Pincoya is said to have long blond hair, be of incomparable beauty, be cheerful and sensual, and rise from the depths of the sea.
==Legends== [[File:ECH 519 53 - Pincoya, La.djvu|left|thumb|Spanish article about the Pincoya from the [[Enciclopedia Chilena]] project, done by the [[Chilean Library of Congress]]]] Naked and pure, she personifies the fertility of marine species. Through her [[ritual dance]] she provides the ''chilote'' (resident of ChiloÃ©) with an abundance or deficiency of fish and seafood. If she performs her dance facing the sea, it means that these shores will have an abundance of fish. When she dances facing the mountains, her back to the sea, seafood will be scarce. [[Chiloean mythology]] is appreciative of the Pincoya, believed to be good, beautiful and humanitarian. According to other legends, Pincoya is the daughter of [[Millalobo]] (king of sea, in chilote mythology) and the human [[Huenchula]]. Her sister is the ''[[Sirena chilota]]'' (a type of [[Mermaid]]) and her brother is ''[[Pincoy]]'' (who also is her husband). The three siblings lead and guide the drowned sailors onto a large phantom ship, ''the [[Caleuche]]'', sailing the seas at night around the southern island of [[ChiloÃ© Island|ChiloÃ©]] in southern [[Chile]]. The ship appears briefly intact with sounds of a party on board, but quickly vanishes. Myth has it that, once on board, the dead can resume an existence as if they were alive again.
==Media== * The Pincoya appears various times in [[The Luke Coles Book Series]] by [[Americans|American]] [[author]] [[Josh Walker (author)|Josh Walker]]. She is first mentioned in Josh Walker's 2014 novel, [[Luke Coles and the Flower of Chiloe]]. In [[Luke Coles and the Forest Assassin]] she brings the spirits of shipwreck victims to the Caleuche before returning to the ocean. <ref>http://www.joshwalkerbooks.com</ref> * It is also mentioned (along with this article) in [[Marisha Pessl]]'s Night Film: A Novel.<ref>{{cite book|last=Pessl|first=Marisha|authorlink=Marisha Pessl|title=Night Film: A Novel|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JDOGofAtJ_YC|date=20 August 2013|publisher=Random House LLC|isbn=978-0-307-36822-5}}</ref> * The Pincoya is playable character in roguelike platform action-adventure game [[Abyss Odyssey]].
==Scientific name use== In 2013, the newly discovered [[Pincoya Storm Petrel]] (''Oceanites pincoyae'') was named after Pincoya.
==References== {{Reflist}} * Martinez Vilches, Oscar, ''Chiloe Misterioso'' (in Spanish). Pub. Ediciones de la Voz de Chiloe (circa 1998)
[[Category:Chilote legendary creatures]] [[Category:Water deities]] [[Category:Water spirits]]
{{Chile-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist | name = A. Scott Denning | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = <!--(filename only, i.e. without "File:" prefix)--> | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = <!--{{birth date |YYYY|MM|DD}}--> | birth_place = | death_date = <!--{{death date and age |YYYY|MM|DD |YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date)--> | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!--{{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline,title}}--> | other_names = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = | fields = [[Atmospheric science]] | workplaces = [[University of California at Santa Barbara]], [[Colorado State University]] | patrons = | alma_mater = [[University of Maine]], Colorado State University | thesis_title = A study of the transport, sources, and sinks of atmospheric COâ using a general circulation model | thesis_url = http://www.worldcat.org/title/study-of-the-transport-sources-and-sinks-of-atmospheric-co-using-a-general-circulation-model/oclc/32483535&referer=brief_results | thesis_year = 1994 | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | influences = | influenced = | awards = Monfort Professor Award from Colorado State University, 2002<ref>{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2457&dat=20080214&id=WtE8AAAAIBAJ&sjid=WC4MAAAAIBAJ&pg=2635,3531964 | title=Talk on climatology | work=[[Bangor Daily News]] | date=14 February 2008 | accessdate=15 September 2014}}</ref> | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | spouse = Yes | partner = <!--(or | partners = )--> | children = 2<ref>[http://biocycle.atmos.colostate.edu/people/scott-denning/ Scott Denning]</ref> | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | website = {{URL|http://www.atmos.colostate.edu/faculty/denning.php}} | footnotes = }} '''A. Scott Denning''' is a climate scientist and professor of atmospheric science at [[Colorado State University]], whose faculty he joined in 1998. He is known for his research into atmosphere-biosphere interactions and [[atmospheric carbon dioxide]].<ref name=colostate>[http://www.atmos.colostate.edu/faculty/denning.php A. Scott Denning]</ref> He firmly supports action to avoid dangerous climate change and has said that the science behind it is "settled".<ref name=saunders/><ref>[https://www2.ucar.edu/atmosnews/opinion/finding-common-ground-climate-change-contrarians Finding Common Ground with Climate-Change Contrarians]</ref> He has also argued that, if no action is taken on the matter, global warming could cause the climate of Colorado to resemble the current climate of its neighbors to the south, such as southern New Mexico, Texas and Mexico.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.greeleytribune.com/news/business/11702001-113/climate-agriculture-colorado-greeley | title=Recent Greeley talks on ag, climate simultaneously bring out optimism, concern | work=[[Greeley Tribune]] | date=11 June 2014 | accessdate=15 September 2014 | author=Brown, Eric}}</ref> ==Education and scientific career== Denning received his BA in geology from the [[University of Maine]] and his MS and PhD in atmospheric science from Colorado State University in 1993 and 1994, respectively.<ref name=colostate/> He then spent two years as an assistant professor in the Donald Bren School of Environmental Science and Management at the [[University of California at Santa Barbara]].<ref name=colostate/> He joined the faculty of Colorado State University in 1998, and become the director of education for the Center for Multi-Scale Modeling of Atmospheric Processes in 2006.<ref name=colostate/> Denning also worked on the [[Orbiting Carbon Observatory]]'s scientific team, and planned to analyze its data prior to its crash in 2009.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/cwire/2009/02/25/25climatewire-after-carbon-observatory-crashes-scientists-a-9853.html?pagewanted=all | title=Scientists Mull Future After Carbon Satellite Crash | work=New York Times | date=25 February 2009 | accessdate=15 September 2014 | author=Morello, Lauren}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/29369312/ns/us_news-environment/t/satellite-failure-delays-case-missing-co/#.VBdhPS5dXN5 | title=Satellite failure delays case of the missing CO2 | work=[[NBC News]] | date=25 February 2009 | accessdate=15 September 2014 | author=Llanos, Miguel}}</ref>
==Debates== Denning has appeared twice at the [[Heartland Institute]]'s [[International Conference on Climate Change]], and is the only non-skeptical scientist to have done so.<ref name=saunders>{{cite web | url=http://blog.sfgate.com/djsaunders/2012/02/23/if-believers-wont-see-debate-will-it-go-away/ | title=If climate scolds wonât see debate, will it go away? | work=[[SFGate]] | date=23 February 2012 | accessdate=15 September 2014 | author=Saunders, Debra J. | authorlink=Debra Saunders}}</ref> In 2011, for instance, Denning debated skeptical climatologist [[Roy Spencer (scientist)|Roy Spencer]] at the 6th International Conference on Climate Change.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/stevezwick/2012/04/30/heartland-channels-alfred-e-newman-and-emily-litella-in-climate-debate/ | title=Heartland Channels Alfred E. Newman And Emily Litella In Climate Debate | work=[[Forbes]] | date=30 April 2012 | accessdate=15 September 2014 | author=Zwick, Steve}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}}
